title: USS Arizona Memorial, Honolulu
address: 1 Arizona Memorial Place, Honolulu, Oahu, HI 96818
review_list:
We advance booked our tour to the USS Arizona Memorial so we wouldn't miss out like we did 16 years ago. It was awesome and a somber experience to take in. To be in the exact location of such a historic event and take in what is all there to see made an impression.

This is a place where you can pay your respect to those lost in the Pearl Harbor attacks. It is a somber place of reflection and remembrance of those fallen during the first day that the United States entered WWII. This is a must see place in Oahu, but please remember to pay respect to the fallen soldiers, for as...


More  



Took a bus tour out for half a day. There's a few museum halls and then a short film, followed by boat ride to memorial and back. Headset is essential.
As an Aussie, I sometimes find American Military memorials full of pomp and glory - but this one is actually very tasteful and quite unique. Worth a half day trip.

Knowing what happened on December 7, 1941, the terror and horror that occurred, now this memorial is peaceful and helpful for those if us that were not born or old enough to remember. This was my third visit and each time has been more beautiful than the last time.

Pearl Harbor is a must visit if you are going to Hawaii. There is so much to see and do and absorb that you should plan on spending the whole day. The Arizona is the highlight of the visit. I recommend watching Pearl Harbor or Tora Tora Tora prior to the visit so that the events are fresh on your...


More  



This visit doesn't take long but is a must see if you visit Honolulu. There is a short boat ride to the memorial (10 minutes or so). The boat takes the prior group back and when it returns with the next group, you reload to return to the museum area. We bought the audio and felt it was definitely worth...


More  



Glad we did visit one of the world's historical place. So many things to see which will bring you back to their times. You still can smell gasoline which probably coming from the sunken ship.

Rating = Go
This was an unexpectedly moving monument. It's a rare glimpse of history and the mechanizations that got the US to become the worlds preeminent power.
The tour is an hour or two depending on how much you want to see. There are two museums within the compound.
Take the kids. It will be fascinating for them to,see...


More  



Wonderful museum, great stories and background information. I was a little disappointed when actually over the Arizona, really couldn't see much other than a rusted hulk under the water. I was expecting glass bottoms where I would be able to actually see something. It was kinda neat to see the fuel oil still dripping up from that long ago...And it...


More  



We came specifically to see this memorial in Pearl Harbor. They did a nice job on the museums, films and memorial.

title: Pearl Harbor / WW II Valor in the Pacific National Monument, Honolulu
address: 1 Arizona Memorial Place, Honolulu, Oahu, HI 96818
review_list:
We visited in 2011 and knowing the history I found it inspirational. I felt sad and thoughtful out there and even found my family names on the memorial wall. I admire the strength of the survivors and that the respect is amazing. Best day.

Because we were with a tour group, we had a set time. This was great. We were given instructions on where and when to be. Then, we were free to explore the grounds, museums, gift shops. The theatre for viewing the movie was comfortable. The ride to the Arizona Memorial was very quiet. We had been told that this was...


More  



If you are on Oahu, you must visit Pearl Harbor. I took my 8 year old son, and we enjoyed learning about the history together. A lot of the exhibits are family orieinted and appeal to kids.
The memorial itself is extremely moving, and my son told me he will never forget Pearl Harbor.
It's a great, educational, and moving...


More  



We were here with our son and his family , it is different to actually see the place then to just hear about it they do a wonderful job of displaying pictures and telling the story leading up to and the attack and the aftermath ,

This is the museum and promenade area before you go out to the USS Arizona. It's definitely worth some time to go through. Recommend the audio (which includes the USS Arizona portion). Although some of what's on the audio can be read in the displays, it is well done and I thought helped structure your visit through the promenade and...


More  



There's so much to see here so take your time and take in the history. It shows what lead up to the attack here, and all the ships, military, and civilians that lost their lives on that day. I always find it to be a very emotional place to visit. You have an awesome view of Pearl Harbor an active...


More  



A MUST SEE for anyone who comes to Oahu. A memorable experience and a moving tribute to those who gave their last full measure of devotion to our country.

You cannot go to Oahu without visiting pearl Harbor. The history of this place is amazing. Wear a hat, no shade. Very hot day when I went. Spent a fortune on water bottles.

I truly believe everyone who goes to Honolulu should take take to visit Pearl Harbor. It is very well done, and you can easily spend 3-4 hours here. You do need to book ahead - there are a few tickets released each morning, but best to get advance tickets to avoid disappointment. Please don't bother with a Roberts Hawaii guide....


More  



You can't help but feel sad by this memorial. I exprerienced the eerie feeling of the memorial considering the that many lives were lost on that infamous day. The memorial stands amazingly preserved and well- maintained and makes me proud of the freedom and bravery it stands for. This place is a must -see for all visitors.

title: Diamond Head State Monument, Honolulu
review_list:
This was an moderate hike for those who don't hike often. Took about 1hour to go up and down however I spent about 30mins alone taking pictures at the summit. Overall great hike!

We took 'The Bus' from the east end of Waikiki, and arrived in about 15 minutes, but it was a 15 minute walk to the entrance to pay our $1 each fee. The climb up was strenuous, and I had to stop once after a great # of stairs. If I wasn't worried about my 64 yr old heart, I...


More  



We hiked Diamond Head Crater and it was a great experience. The sites you get when you get to the top are awesome. We went first thing in the morning before it got too warm out. It was not a tiring hike up, a few rests and water breaks to look around was all that was needed.

We found parking in the lot when we arrived at 9 a.m. Hike up crowded but great views from the top. And, neat experience to be on/in the crater. Wear sturdy shoes. Bring water.

The hike to the top of Diamond Head is a nice one. If you plan to hike up to see the sunrise you have to plan to arrive early. Leave plenty of time to get there as traffic in and around Honolulu is terrible in the early morning. The view of Waikiki from the top is very good. With a...


More  



We didn't do this until our second trip to Oahu and I'm so glad we did. We went around 10am, and it was busy, but not unbearable. The actual hike up the hill was easy and well paved in a lot of areas. All ages could easily do this hike.
The views from the top are amazing and well worth...


More  



It is a bit tougher climb than i expected but well worth it! i'm so glad I did it. awesome views and sense of accomplishment.

This is certainly worth the effort . Parking can be difficult so avoid WE. The trip to the summit of the crater is relatively easy . Some parts are a little streneous but nothing that most people cannot do ( we are 75 and 80 ). Very crowded so take your time and be patient and you will be rewarded...


More  



It was truly an experience climbing up. It took us an hour to climb up on a very hot day but it was all worth it when I reached the top. A non interrupted views of the Island, as far as your eyes can see.

We did this walk first up in the morning! Although it was very crowded, it was a nice walk and has awesome views of Oahu. A must do when in Hawaii.

title: Battleship Missouri Memorial, Honolulu
review_list:
My wife and I took the Memorial Tour and found it most interesting. It was not too strenuous or difficult to traverse the interior of the ship. I'm 64 and had hip replacement surgery in 2015 and had no problems. We spent about 3 hrs on the ship.

Visiting the USS Missouri should not be missed while in Pearl Harbor. The basic price includes a very interesting and informative 30 minute overview with one of the guides, plus a headset to use at selected spots on the ship that provided additional details plus stories from Vets. We spent about 2 hours total on board. You can get there...


More  



The ship has so much to see on it, the guides are very informative and really bring it to life. To stand in the place where they signed the document with the Japanese to end the war is an amazing feeling. It's a huge ship and stands watch over Pearl Harbour. Very impressive tour.

This was amazing experience! Take the guided tour during early morning hours. This was the guides have time to stop and talk longer and answer specific questions you might have regarding the ship.
I had an amazing guide who was very knowledgeable about the history of the ship, US navel history in the Pacific, and the actual battles fought by...


More  



A visit to the Missouri is a must while you are in Pearl Harbor. We took the hard hat tour which allows you to go below the tourist decks to see the inner workings of the ship. A guide is provided. We had a great time. And spent more time than we thought we would.

Went here with my family and my son is a history and military buff. He loved the initial tour. When they turned us loose to walk the ship is when I had my fun. I loved investing the internal parts of the ship. Wish they would open up more decks. Well worth the price of admission.

A great look back in time on a ship that had been through it all. We spent a long afternoon on the Mighty Mo and it was well worth it.
A warning though, it was a hot day and you need to bring a bottle of water. They have refilling stations and you will need it.

It's amazing to walk around the battleship - really puts you back in time. The volunteer who gave us our tour was so knowledgeable. We did have the audio, but forgot to use it as the tour guide was awesome.

The ship is impressive but the highlight was the free tour included in admission (admission is like $25 per person). Take the tour. They talk about the boat's history, the sigining of the surrender and the kamikaze attack. They provide a very fair treatment to both sides in the conflict. It's only about 30 minutes then you can wander the...


More  



If you enjoy warship / military history this is for you... great trip that I'd do again. Toured the whole ship apart from the engine room which was off bounds. WW2 history lecture was great & the background of how the ship served in Desert Storm eye opening

title: Hanauma Bay Nature Preserve, Honolulu
address: 100 Hanauma Bay Drive, ueber Kalanianaole Highway, Honolulu, Oahu, HI 96825
review_list:
I was excited to snorkel this place since it was a preserve and expected to see beautiful coral and a lot of fish. Unfortunately most of the coral appeared dead which is probably the result of too many people touching it. The coral started to improve as I got closer to the buoys but it was windy that day and...


More  



I didn't get to go to Hanauma Bay the last time I was in Hawai'i and was very excited to go this time. And I wasn't disappointed.
I understand there are long lines to get in at some points during the day, but we went around 2:30 pm and walked right in. We brought our own fins and snorkles so...


More  



The best snorkeling I've seen on oahu in terms of fish, water calmness and clarity. There are, however, a few drawbacks. The parking lot fills up it gets so busy and the beach is very crowded. The walk to the beach is a bit far, but Do-able for most. There are shuttles but they're not free.
I would highly recommend...


More  



After seeing pictures of Hanauma Bay I felt like this was a must. The water was beautiful and the fish were lovely!
Tips: bring water, snacks and sunscreen since there's nothing to buy down there
Bring a beach may ($3-$4 from ABC soooooo worth it!!)
The beach was super crowded and I felt like I was bumping into others snorkeling...


More  



What an amazing place to snorkel and experience view the underwater marine life. We saw Parrot Fish and a Sea Turtle. So many other types of fish. We are rookies to snorkeling but so much fun. We are back again this year and will try to do it again.

Upside: You wont find a prettier beach in a more idyllic setting. A small bay shelters a sandy, relatively shallow approximately .7 mile long beach. Two principal activities: (a) bring or rent gear and you can observe the coral reef and a multitude of fish) or/and (b) wade in up to your knees and the fish will come right up...


More  



Beautiful place to snorkel, lots of fish. Go early as it is very busy !!! Also bring your own equipment, mask and snorkel only is $12 flippers extra

This was probably once a very beautiful snorkeling area, too many people have damaged the coral reef life. We've been to better snorkeling places in the Caribbean. Too many people here for us.

I have snorkeled/dove a far amount around the world and I think that is a must do. Seldom will you see so many beautiful fish in one very accessible location. The park is closed on Tuesdays, so go on Wednesday to see the most fish at their most relaxed. Be sure to go early because the parking fills up and...


More  



$1 parking and $7.50 per person entry seemed expensive, but the snorkeling was much better than I expected, considering the number of people in the water. Onsite mask/fin rental is $20, so bring your own if possible. Undersea lava formations make for interesting habitat for many turtles, fish, shellfish - in fairly calm waters about 5-10 feet deep.

title: National Memorial Cemetery of the Pacific, Honolulu
review_list:
We took the Bus from Waikiki to Punchbowl, then it was quite a walk to the front gate (about 15 minutes). I was a little surprised there is no 'visitor center', but we were given a brochure and information from a gentleman at the 'head' office. The map was a must have for us to find the graves of 442nd...


More  



We went looking for a relatives site and were able to find it easily because of the way they have things arranged and marked.

The cemetery is really serene and well laid out The monument is very beautiful. However, the best thing (particularly from a history lover's pov) is the maps/history engravings within the memorial. It lays out the entire history of WWII, Korea and Vietnam in map form. It's very concise and educational.

This was a destination with our Discovery Tour drive through Honolulu. We were not allowed to leave our vehicle, but this was an absolutely beautiful must see destination.

One highlight of our recent stay in Honolulu was our visit to the Punchbowl cemetery. This place memorializes the sacrifice of the thousands of men & women.

This is a spot where you can spend hours wandering the vast fields reading grave stones. The Memorial Wall is fascinating. We will visit this place again.

We went to visit this place as part of a day trip around the island. Its kept beautifully in fact immaculate. Good to see the respect of those that have passed and so well maintained. A quiet beautiful place to visit. A must do.

Sad you cant get out and walk around to due past vandalism- would vandals dare to to the same at Arlington? So why here? As in both cemeteries, its not about the famous laid to rest but the collective who made the ultimate sacrifice.

We got to see this memorial as part of our round island tour & the bus drives you round the memorial. Ernie Pyle is buried inbetween 2 unknown soldiers which was his wish. RIP to the fallen.

Great place to view the city of Honolulu, very quiet and peaceful, well taken care of,. Have been there many times and went again couple weeks again. Beautiful well kept grounds, flowers blooming. Not allowed to have food there.

title: USS Bowfin Submarine Museum & Park, Honolulu
address: 11 Arizona Memorial Drive, Honolulu, Oahu, HI 96818-3104
review_list:
I really enjoyed touring this submarine. The sub itself is very interesting and if you take the audio tour there is much to learn as you go from section to section of it. Included in the fee to see the sub is also an admission for the museum of submarine history. Both attractions were great too see, informative, and had...


More  



The Bowfin has an unbelievable history and she welcomes you into a world that was one of the most dangerous in all of WWII. The tour through her narrow passageways and tight living space is one that will stay with you forever. Those who served on her and other subs during WWII were certainly heroes.

It is like a walk back in time. You can see so many actual historical remnants from WWII. You can place yourself in the exact spot that a veteran would have been in.

One of the most successful submarines in the US Navy from WWII. The self-paced tour is well worth taking time over, and then visiting the Submarine Museum. We will go back.

Check this out! Audio tour is a must - so much great info. Really interesting to see how the crew lived and worked. Even if you are not a war buff or history buff the tour is interesting.

I visited the submarine in Baltimore harbor, and without knowing anything about subs, was very happy to be able to compare 2 very different classes. Equally, the museum was insightful. Took a good hour to do it right.

I did not know that combat submarines and torpedoes had been around as long as they have and how advanced they were early on.

I highly recommend this, and all the attractions at Pearl Harbor.
I can not say enough about it. GO SEE IT !!
Plan the entire day, there is a lot to see. Take your time and enjoy it.

The boat (Yes..submarines are referred to as boats) is well preserved and the audio tour was fantastic. Very informative and enjoyable!

We enjoyed the Bowfin tour. It is really cool to see. That said if your time is short spend it on the Missouri tour. We took about an hour or a little more for this tour. That time cut our Missouri tour a little short, but I could have stayed there all day. In short, got time? Then go for...


More

title: Koko Crater Trail, Honolulu
address: Koko Head Park Rd, Honolulu, Oahu, HI 96825
review_list:
My day job involves risk assessment and safety so when I arrived at the base of the Koko Head rail/trail I could see that the lengthy disclaimer on the signs setting out climb at own risk etc had been put in place for a reason. The climb to the rim of the Koko head crater is up an abandoned rail...


More  



My only advice is don't try this if you aren't in shape. There is also a section where you literally walk across railroad ties over a ravine.I recommend walking around. Easily the most difficult hike I've done it's not even a mile long. Views at the top make you quickly foget the work to get to the top. Going down...


More  



This is not for faint of heart or people who are not in shape. I do the climb whenever I am in Honolulu which is often. I workout twice a day normally. It's so steep that I don't even look up as it can be defeating. There are spots walking over railroad ties that people do on their butts. This...


More  



It's February, and the plumeria trees at the beginning of the trail are just coming into bloom. Who knew there are so many marvelous colors of plumeria? The terrain is uneven, so wear good walking shoes.

This is not a hike for small kids or anyone that's pretty out of shape. It's a steep hike to the top up old railroad tracks, and at one point over a bridge with nothing underneath it. It's a strenuous climb and you'll definitely feel it after, but keep going! When you start to ask yourself if it's worth it,...


More  



Great exercise, while enjoying the view! Challenging, to say the least. Saw some marines with their heavy backpacks running up the 1,000 or more steps of the trail, quick paced. Amazing! Made me appreciate the discipline in training of the navy.

Very challenging but worth it. A definite sense of accomplishment and the view is spectacular. I would recommend going around the bridge. The risk would not be worth it if you fell.

Around 1400 steps to thAround 1400 steps to the top. Very good exercise. Good light wind refreshed our burned from the sun bodies. The view on both sides mountains is amazing. You can see Hanauma Bay, Diamond Head ...Costco warehouse 😆😆.
MUST SEE
DRINK A LOT OF WATER.

We climbed Koko head mid Feb 2016. It's 1220 Meters of crazy vertical hike. It's not a trail for the under 10 crowd, take them to Diamond Head instead if they want to hike.
Koko head is right across from popular Hanauma bay. To get there it's about 20 min east of waikiki. The beach bus 22 gets you right...


More  



This was not an easy walk up or down but it is completely worth it. Wear good comfortable shoes and take lots of water, it's a busy track and very steep but if you take your time all fitness levels are able to get to the top

title: Shangri La, Honolulu
address: Tours arranged through Honolulu Museum of Art, 900 South Beretania Street, Honolulu, Oahu, HI 96814
review_list:
Doris Duke's Hawaii home is a treasure of Islamic art and architecture. Each room has amazing artistic details, furniture, and more. It's really breathtaking. No pictures are allowed in the house, only from the gardens -- which are beautiful and over look the ocean. Make reservations in advance. There are very few tours each week. Visitors must take the shuttle...


More  



Doris Duke had the most amazing eye for beauty and proportions. This tour of her Diamond Head home, arranged through the Honolulu Art Museum, was a highlight of our time in Oahu. From the meshrabiyya in the entrance to the Damascus room to her famed bedroom, the house opens to room after room of breathtaking beauty, objects d'art, priceless antiques...


More  



Timeless. Eternal. Peaceful.
The story of Shangri-La and it's visionary, Doris Duke, makes this slice of otherworldly paradise vibrant and well worth the visit. Ms. Duke has created a home designed for privacy and seclusion and then filled it with beautiful art and artifacts. The comfortable rooms, peaceful outdoor spaces and stunning views make Shangri-La so very unique.
Don't go...


More  



Despite having visited Hawaii many times over the years I only learned of this recently. Visits can only be had if arranged in advance from the Honolulu Museum of Art.
The personal story of Doris Duke is quite sad, but she did collect many beautiful pieces primarily from the Islamic world. She displayed them in a breath-taking site in a...


More  



This is a beautiful relic of old Hawaii, old Hollywood, amazing islamic art. It's like the epicenter of scacred geometry in Honolulu.
The house it's self is breathtaking. The stories of Doris Duke is magical and captivating. When you look out over the water you can almost feel like you are living here.
It's beautiful, it's magnificent and it made...


More  



The Doris Duke Mansion(heiress to the cigarette dynasty & donor of Duke University) & Honolulu Museum was recommended by a local resident. We did the booking on line. It is only open certain days of week and certain times; limited groups(booking in advance highly recommended). The home is filled with articles that can never be in any home of today:...


More  



Rich and famous tobacco heiress Doris Duke loved Islamic art, she built this beautiful Islamic home in the late 1930s, on the best spot in Honolulu overlooking the Pacific Ocean.
When you walk in Shangri La, it’s like walking in different world. It’s filled with precious Islamic antiques and art work--- the whole wall, fireplace, ceiling, arch and columns--- Duke...


More  



Visited Shangri La recently and enjoyed being in this beautiful, amazing home / estate. Formerly owned by tobacco heiress Doris Duke, the public can now visit by booking a tour through the Honolulu Museum of Art. You MUST book a tour, you cannot just stop by the estate and hope they'll let you in. The tour actually starts at the...


More  



If you have a chance - pre book this tour well in advance. The groups are small and space is very limited but boy was this a worthwhile one to take. Doris Duke was amazing - I want to come back as her! Her home was a monument to Islamic art - beautiful. Highly recommend this tour and don't miss...


More  



We didn't know what to expect since since we are not into Islamic art, but thought we would give it a try. The house is a museum in itself and the sheer volume of priceless artifacts is amazing. The owner of the home, Doris Duke (now deceased), was such an interesting person. Hearing her story alone was worth the trip....

title: Bishop Museum, Honolulu
review_list:
If you are interested in Hawaii and its history this museum is a must. Lots of artifacts dating prior to the US occupation and annexion showing how the Hawaiian natives lived , their aspirations.
Lots of exhibits also on fauna and flora.
There is too much in the museum for one single visit but you can easily select according to...


More  



Took "The Bus" (#2 from Waikiki; $2.50). It was SO EASY to get there with out a car. I specifically wanted to learn about the Hawaiian culture and reviews said this was it.
The Bishop has a day-long set of docent-led tour choices from history, volcanic science, and astronomy that are part of the admission fee. I followed their suggestions...


More  



This is one of my favorite museums anywhere, and therefore it's $20+ admission (plus parking) is not that surprising. It's collection is massive and the curation is exemplary. Add the charm of the docents and the local culture and you have a world class experience. Since the collection cannot be absorbed in one visit, management might consider reducing the sticker...


More  



A popular site for school trips, this museum has the most comprehensive overview of Hawaiian culture and history. Budget a few hours to make sure you get the most out of the experience. The main hall was my favorite part with all the historical artifacts, but the science hall was a lot of fun and featured a lot of interactive...


More  



While the architecture is fantastic, the actual museum is eye-opening. Many exhibits showing the history of the Hawaiian people and the coming of the West.
The cost was quite high, we thought, but we did it anyway.

The museum provides valuable, even essential, background, on Hawaii before statehood. It presents the version of history that the missionaries, federal government, and outside businesses can't be proud of -- the story of how a legitimate ruler and culture were overrun. Not a theme unknown in other parts of the country, or the world, for that matter. Other collections in...


More  



A wonderful afternoon was spent at the Bishop Museum!
Built in honor of the last descendant of the royal Kamehameha family, the Bishop Museum houses a series of rooms and buildings dedicated to the preservation of Pacific art, culture and science. The grand Hawaiian Hall showcases the history of the islands from the ancient to the modern. Exhibits include the...


More  



Bishop Museum is exquisite, beautiful, interesting, full of Hawaiian history, with beautiful grounds, and a restaurant to relax in. There's nothing else quite like Bishop Museum. You will love it!

We got to Hawaii frequently. When we are in Honolulu, we look forward to visiting the Bishop Museum. This time we had two wonderful docents who tag teamed the culture of Micronesia. My favorite was an exhibit of the 442 Infantry Regiment, the most decorated in WWII history.

We wanted to learn about Hawaiian culture and Royalty. Bishop Museum is inspirational. The main alone is worth the visit. Going inside and learning everything is perfect. Everyone there were very helpful and nice.

title: Makapuu Lighthouse Trail, Honolulu
address: Near the Hawaii Kai Golf Course on Kalanianaole Highway, Honolulu, Oahu, HI
review_list:
This trail was a fairly easy hike. I would suggest going very early in the morning because it gets very busy around 9-10 and it is hard to find parking.

Great place with some stunning views and big chances for seeing the whales. The trail itself is not too long for a walkers like me, it was just perfect.

A nice , easy and well established trail to the lighthouse and the viewpoints above it. From there you can see a good stretch of the North shore.
Also on the way up watch for whales . A number of free binocular stations help you see the whales coming out of the water.

The trail has been recently repaved, it is a gently sloping asphalt trail that is about a mile from bottom to top. There are several viewing areas along the trail that provide great views of the ocean and the lighthouse. The top viewing area is still under construction, but there is a lower viewing area open where you can look...


More  



Everyone talks about Diamondhead but this one is much better. Less crowded. Less strenuous. Better views and more of them. It's about the same distance as well.

Busy little spot - but well worth the walk up the paved road to the top. Great views and a nice little workout.

This hike will make you work, but with the paved pathway is accessible for small children, the stroller crowd, etc. If you go late Jan through early April you might be treated with the site of breaching Humpback whales in the water. A must for working off all those mai tais you have had on your vacation.

First glance made us question our choice because the parking lot was full but we found a spot soon enough. The walk had a decent incline but multiple nice, marked viewpoints and many chances to risk it and find a way to the rocky shoreline. Spotted a great number of whales, breathed in the ocean breeze, saw ships and sail...


More  



The parking lots were so full that our friend had to wait in the car for us, and no spot opened up until just when we were returning to the car. The views down Sandy beach are breathtaking, the shades of the water from turquoise green and blue shading into navies and purples. You could watch the waves break on...


More  



After reading all the reviews, I knew I had to make a trip out here. Get here early to get parking and to avoid the hot sun and big tourist groups. It's a short hike with many places to rest and catch your breath. Take your time and enjoy the views.

title: Iolani Palace, Honolulu
address: 364 South King Street, Honolulu, Oahu, HI 96813
review_list:
Great place to step back in time, the wood work is amazing, the tour guides are really passionate about there jobs. If you have never been its a must to do.

I'm a big fan of Hawaii Five O so I was excited to stand under the Statue of the King. The fountain is beautiful and the gardens around the Palace are so exotic.

A great place. Obviously unique. If you visit Hawaii, you really should go here. Tour guide was rather too unfriendly, very unusual for Hawaii. Overall a must see.

The tour of the palace provides good historical information about Hawaii and it's royalty. Our tour guide was knowledgeable and if you have an interest in history or architecture I think you'd enjoy this tour.

We took our kids 10,8,6 and 3 to visit Iolani Palace. It was a great experience and we learned a lot of history and culture. We read a book about Lilioukalani (sp?) before we came so my kids were thrilled to see some of the figures in the book in a real life context. Our docent was knowledgeable and friendly....


More  



You have to admit, it's fun polishing the floors when wearing those booties! All visitors are required to slip on cloth shoe covers to protect the floors. I didn't realize the guided tours were offered only during the morning. The self-guided audio tour was well done, allowed us to go at our own pace, and provided the option for summary...


More  



Hawaii was its own nation prior to the overthrow of the monarchy and Iolani Palace is a great place to learn the history. Being able to walk the halls of Hawaii's Kings and Queens is a unique experience for anyone who visits the Islands.

We truly enjoyed our tour and tour guide thru the Iolani Palace. It will be something that I will take all my visiting guests to.

I reviewed the Palace tour in November when we took visitors on a tour led by a docent. We enjoyed the Palace itself but the docent did not add much from my perspective. I thought it would have been a different experience with another docent, although I still thought it was excellent. This time, we did the independent Audio Tour....


More  



We scheduled the last self-guided audio tour (4:00) of the day and upon arrival we were immediately told, essentially, to "hurry up" because they close at 5. What the hell? I had to skip over some of the audio content just so I could get through the entire site. I am strongly of the belief that the last tour of...


More

title: Manoa Falls, Honolulu
address: End of Manoa Road, Honolulu, Oahu, HI 96822
review_list:
This was a really beautiful walk, and easy enough for most fitness levels and kids! The falls are a little weak lately, but the hike is nice enough without a powerful waterfall anyway. It was a nice way to spend he afternoon, and I definitely recommend it if you're looking to get out of the crazy city!

Except the last 300 yards and some discreet stretches in between this is an easy trail , well marked.
Beautiful tropical vegetation. Not recommended after or during rainfall as ground can be slippery.
Use of walking stick would help.
The trail ends with a waterfall in a small pool.
Very enjoyable and relaxing after the noise and crowds of Waikiki.

It's an easy trail through a beautiful rain forest. This is the Hawaii everyone imagines. Get there early!

Paid $5 to park near the restaurant and then started the walk in. Paved at first, then giving way to dirt and rock. Very well marked, slick in parts if it's wet out or has rained recently. 10 story (?) high fall and small pond at termination. Marked not to get in or near but people were swimming in it...


More  



We are always looking for a new adventure on our holidays, we love nature and love to get away from the cities. This hike is just a short drive from Honolulu and easy to find. We paid $5 for parking and had no problems as some people suggest, our rental car was all intact when we returned. As with any...


More  



This slice of paradise is in the heart of the manoa valley. A easy hike throught the lush hawaiian landscape, seemingly takes you back in time. A highlight!

Make sure to wear good sturdy shoes. Camera is a must bring also. Loved all the beauty to see and walk way is well maintained. Little babies less than 3 should be carried by parent, too many rocks, sticks to trip over. Great for entire family

The views along the hike are movie like. The hike seems like it never ends. When you get closer to the falls the mud got slippery. For us it was worse than the rocks at the waterfall. Kids enjoyed the hike. It took us like 30min up hill or so it seemed. The waterfall only flows a lot when it...


More  



Very close to Waikiki - no road signs to show you which way to go - above the University on Manoa DR - just keep following Manoa Rd until it ends at a small parking lot where it will cost you $5 to park your car - approx 1 - 1 1/2 hour round trip. Last 1/3 of the trail...


More  



This hike is medium-hard. Anyone with average fitness level should be able to complete it. Not good for anyone with difficulty walking as the terrain is bumpy and you're walking over rocks at times. Quite busy with tourists, but the forest is absolutely breathtaking. Waterfall was okay but hike overall was beautiful.

title: Waikiki Beach, Honolulu
review_list:
This beach is way to crowded if you don't come early enough. We also had birds eating at our snacks on the beach. Otherwise, it's a nice local beach.

Everyone loves Waikiki! There is nowhere like it. But....
Be ready for a crowd. Dukes is nearby and there is The statue of Duke - with the live webcam... That is truly a-lot of fun.
When you go plan on a long walk to the car. There is a dropoff point, and with some planning you can have have one...


More  



This is a very beautiful beach that is right next to the hotel districts of Waikiki. It is very beautiful, but very crowded and busy, I prefer the north end of the Island for their bigger waves.

not at all what I expected for a tourist beach .all you are allowed to do on this beach is sunbake and swim, they don't allow alcohol drinks , ball games ,any games, pets, you can just sit or swim and that's it

The beach is average and is mostly crowded. There are much nicer beaches on the island. But it does have the history and fir someone who visited it many times over many years it means something.
Do visit it, spend a little time there but go outside of Waikiki to enjoy the other beautiful beaches of this island

A walk on Waikiki beach is certainly a must , but choice the time and day to avoid overcrowding. Walking on the beach is difficult as it can be packed . The beach is relatively narrow and interrupted by concrete piers ( not pleasant barefoot ) and cables ( boat anchoring ).
Nevertheless it is a pleasant experience doing one...


More  



If you like big cities, lots of noise, crowds, shoppers, and homeless people - this is the place for you. I couldn't wait to get out of here. I did go swimming/snorkeling, wasn't bad, but there are better spots. Tourist TRAP!

The beach is the most famous natural wonder in Honolulu.This white sand beach front along the bustling thoroughfare in the heart of Honolulu amid the backdrop of hotels and condos is still an important tourist destination.

The Waikiki beach was beautiful and so convenient since I was staying at a hotel across the street. The beach was pretty crowded had a lot of families at one part and more adults on the other.
Iconic beach if you're staying in Waikiki....if you're really far away I would say go to a beach closer (yea I can't believe...


More  



1 of the top beaches in the world, and for a reason. Beautiful, awesome walking path alongside the beach with restaurants and bars on it.
The only down side is there is no shade at all unless you sit far from the beach. You can rent a beach chair and umbrella for 50$ per day which is disgustingly expensive.

title: Fort DeRussy Beach Park, Honolulu
review_list:
Pretty okay park, lots of shade. Nothing special, worth a look. Easy to get too. I enjoyed it. It's a why not kinda thing.

This large park is well maintained and stretches all the way down to the beach. A great place to setup a net for volleyball or to have a picnic lunch. String a hammock between two trees and take a nap. Also offers affordable parking nearby for military members.

Great walk along the beach, wonderful place to watch a sunset! The fireworks on Friday night at the Hilton Hawaiian Village at 7:45 p.m. are not to be missed.

We found this beach quite calm and peaceful. The swimming was enjoyable and the weather was fantastic. The beach itself is somewhat rocky so be a bit careful getting into the water. Shallow for quite a distance and quite safe. Lifeguards on duty during the day.

During one of our walks we end up in this park. It is well care for and a nice place to enjoy a walk.

Waikiki beach can be heavily populated. The beach located in front of this park is great. Offers plenty of space to choose. Same idealic views. Water great. Suggest you wear shoes to walk in the water as small rocks in deeper parts of beach.

The U.S. government made a wise choice so many years ago to secure all the area where Fort DeRussy is located. Part of it is no longer a military installation but a lovely park for all the public to enjoy. You frequently see people picnicking in the park, lounging on the grass, playing volleyball and enjoying the wonderful sandy beach...


More  



My wife and I went to the park multiple times over the course of 5 days. Evening walks to see the sunset, bike rides in the morning, playing in the beach in the afternoon and much more.
Good place to be.

We had the perfect view of Ft DeRussy beach park for our 14 days on Oahu, and one sea lion decided to sun bath below on the beach

We thought the park was beautiful and well maintained. In the evening, we noticed some homeless people at the picnic tables at the edge of the park. They were minding their own business and not bothering anyone. We also noticed some US Army servicemen around during the day.

title: Honolulu Museum of Art, Honolulu
address: 900 S. Beretania Street, Honolulu, Oahu, HI 96814 (Formerly Honolulu Academy of Arts)
review_list:
Free for kids under 17, this was a perfect respite from the midday sun and a nice change of pace from all the beach activities. The collection is small but thoughtful and the temporary exhibit on Harajuku Tokyo Street fashion was a big hit with our teenage girls.

My wife and I are annual members and will be renewing our membership. This museum has an impressive amount of art from around the Pacific and the world at large. The Shang-ri-la exhibit is a must see and we really enjoy the rotating exhibits. The café is delicious and a nice place for lunch. Parking is a little tough around...


More  



Special exhibits of Hiroshige prints, Harajuku and contemporary Japanese lithographer were shown. The latter two added some punch to visit. Place is partitioned into themed courtyards which are serene areas of tranquility. Even when there are hordes of school kids teeming through one can find your own art space. Always enjoy their contemporary exhibits, there was a Motherwell and Ruscha...


More  



The exhibits at the Museum of Art divide into Western Art to the right and Eastern art to the left. The Japanese print section was spare, but interesting, as was the collection of Islamic art, many of the pieces part of the Doris Duke donation. My favorite exhibit was a playful exhibit of Japanese current fashion, including exquisite dresses in...


More  



With our visit to Shangri-La, we had access to the Honolulu Museum of Art and decided to visit the galleries after our return from the Doris Duke estate. Glad we went!
The galleries at the museum offer works from the ancient world, great masters and new artists. The impressive collection is set in a labyrinth of rooms and is well...


More  



Beautiful museum, near downtown Honolulu, and not far from Ala Moana Center, with many great exhibits and beautiful installations. Admission is $10.00

We stumbled upon this museum on our way to China Town. What a great find. They were having a display of students art and it was fantastic.
Some very tallented young people.
The staff were very friendly and helpful and the place was a lovely old building.
Free to enter.

Surprisingly good Museum. Totally unexpected. Never crowded. Very good art and other artifacts. A nice quiet experience.

We did not have a car during our stay in Waikiki, but took the city transit that dropped us off at the front entrance of the museum. The return trip meant going over one block as the street is only a one-way traffic road. I was pleasantly surprised in the overall collection and liked seeing how how the displays were...


More  



The museum of art had quite a lot of displays that covered major cultures, movements and periods of art. We were pleasantly surprised with quality and breadth of the collection. Highly recommend for anyone that appreciates art and museums.

title: US Army Museum of Hawaii, Honolulu
review_list:
My family would often walk past the museum without every stopping in. We finally took the time and boy was it worth it. While the history/military buff will love it, it is a neat museum for everyone since it is help in the bowels of an old fort. My daughter felt like she was sneaking through an old prison/castle with...


More  



This was quite a discovery! A very good exhibit of the Hawaiian involvement in WW2, especially of the Japanese immigrants. One entire room was a surprise to a 4 star General (You need to visit to find out who!)

I have been here a half dozen times over the years and I never miss the chance to visit when in Waikiki. They operate on donation and are staffed by volunteers.
The displays are Smithsonian quality and uniquely tailored to Hawaiians contributions to various wars. The facility is nothing short of an engineering marvel and was thankfully spared from the...


More  



A venue that only survives through the dedication by its volunteers,retaining the local history and preserves those that ensured the final outcome. Visited by all nationalities.

As an Army veteran and being born and raised in the Hawaiian islands I've always been fascinated with military history. The Army Museum of Hawaii was an excellent place for this! They took time in creating great exhibits and the attention to detail was outstanding. They also incorporated a historical facility into the museum. Fort DeRussy was the home of...


More  



Great location just off the beach at Waikiki, near the Hilton and Hale Koa. The museum is housed in a former bunker used in coastal defense. Portion of the museum is devoted to former Army Chief of Staff, Eric Shinseki, a native of Hawaii.

great little museum with well stocked, interesting gift shop. At the moment they have an excellent exhibit all about the role of many Nisei in the Military Intelligence Service during WW2 and what a huge difference they made - I thought it was fascinating and really well done.

We did not plan to visit the museum but were walking by, were very hot, and decided to stop in for a few minutes. It would up being a longer stay. I am a veteran so the museum was more interesting to me than my wife. While covering general topics related to the U.S. Army, the emphasis is appropriately on...


More  



We had one hour gap between after lunch and another activity. We were really just hope to kill some time at this place. However, we were amazed by how much we learnt about Hawaii & its history after the visit. It is free to visit this place, but make sure you make a some donation. We certainly did.

This free museum has a lot of interesting information. Most of the genuine relics are at Pearl Harbour and the new aviation museum but we learnt a lot about other conflicts. I especially enjoyed getting a bit more insight into the day to day lives of the participants.

title: Tantalus Lookout Puu Ualakaa State Park, Honolulu
address: Round Top Drive, Honolulu, Oahu, HI 96822
review_list:
We were fortunate to be able to visit this park as part of our personalised tour with Kevin from escapwaikikitours.com as it is not an easy place to find. The view at sunset of Waikiki from the summit was amazing and spectacular.

Nice relaxing drive with a great view. They have places where uou can stop to take pictures. We had a great afternoon.

Take your time on your drive up around Tantalus... drive with your windows (or top) down and radio off so you can hear all the birds. Enjoy the canopy of trees overhead and glimpses of waterfalls and the ocean. Stop at the Lookout for some great photos.

I did a photo shoot up here for my church and was pleasantly surprised to find a State Park at the top. There was plenty of parking, and perhaps even a wedding ceremony taking place during my visit. There is a roadside scenic spot just before the park entrance which is also a great site for photos. Check it out...


More  



We visited with our two children aged three and five. We drove to the top first and took in the views over Honolulu (magnificent). We then walked down to the trailhead. The first thing we realized was that the trails would not accommodate a stroller. Fortunately, our three year old happily climbed out of the stroller and started clambering up...


More  



This is a quick but highly recommended stop on your drive along the Tantalus Scenic Drive. The overlook views of the broad panorama from Diamond Head, Waikiki, Honolulu and the airport to the west are awesome. Several panorama pictures are needed. Easy to find and adequate parking. It was not busy both times we stopped there. No fees. Restrooms in...


More  



if you've seen a great shot of someone overlooking honolulu, this is the place. an easy drive, easy parking, and never crowded; at least not for more than a couple of minutes. take your turn in the corner and get that great 'i was there' shot. then stay and enjoy cause you might be the only people there. if not,...


More  



After leaving Punchbowl Cemetery we took the Tantalus/Roundtop Drive since it was just a very short distance away. You feel like you are far away from the city, even though it's only like 10 minutes away.
We took Tantalus Dr. Going up and then it changes into Roundtop on the way down. It's a beautiful, but very twisty turny road....


More  



We drove up the tantalus at around 9 pm. It was so dark and kinda scary to drive if you are not familiar. For tourists better hire someone local who is familiar if you wanna see the honolulu city lights at night. The view is beautiful and it was kind of windy and cold. This is a must.

The drive up is beautiful along an ancient rain forest with hairpin turns but take your time and enjoy the lush gardens.

title: Saint Augustine by-the-Sea, Honolulu
review_list:
The church is beautiful, especially when the sun is moving through the windows! The service was a little hard to hear and was not a style I prefer (as I enjoy more lively priests) but was still very enjoyable.
It is a church worth visiting for its beauty!

A nice old church with welcoming church committee members and parishioners, a place of worship where one can
find some peaceful and quiet time during a busy, hectic week of touring Oahu..since the church has no a/c it was hot despite the breeze especially because so many churchgoer went during the Palm Sunday ceremony

The glitzy Waikiki hotels tower above the pointed roof of St. Augustine by-the-Sea. Yet it still stands out as a significant structure along the shoreline. This parish is so welcoming to the many visitors who come to worship while on vacation. It is a spiritual home away from home.

Our hotel was next door to this church and our room overlooked the church with a view of the beach/ocean. Well, what a treat we were entertained by the most heavenly singers when their choir would rehearse in the courtyard a couple of times a week. My daughter and husband attended a service and it was the anniversary mass for...


More  



We attended the early morning mass and it was a beautiful service. We were greated and welcomed into the church. It was nice to not feel like an outsider/tourist. Everyone we met were very nice. The walk down Kalakaua Ave to and from the church was easy.

We attend Mass here whenever in Honolulu and find it to be a spiritual, beautiful ceremony/location. The priests are welcoming and friendly with excellent homily every time we have been there. Attendees are local, tourists, and homeless. Beautiful interior. Ushers are welcoming and sincere in their efforts to facilitate the ceremony. Thank you all!!! Highlight of my trip.

This church is a commination of Tradition and Polynesian.
Very friendly congregation,
Beautiful interior

Was pleased to see the church packed on a Saturday evening, sound system was a bit loud, but otherwise, the homily and service was top notch.

I pass by this place every time I'm in Waikiki and always wondered what it looked like on the inside. Took a peak and loved the architecture of the cathedral.

My wife and I always do our best to make it to Mass every time we are in Hawaii the services here have always been so beautiful and great experience in the native tongue and you don't have to be Catholic to enjoy and give thanks to the Big Guy for being alive and in Hawaii.

title: Magic Island, Honolulu
address: 1201 Ala Moana Blvd, At the end of Ala Moana Beach Park, Honolulu, Oahu, HI 96814
review_list:
So many activities at Magic island. I saw at least 5 weddings a day. In the mornings, there are numerous sessions of yoga on paddle boards. Lots of family and friends picnics, many with roast pigs on their tables. Fishing, paddle boarding, surfing, swimming -- a fun place to bring the whole family.

This a big patch of grass that sticks out into the ocean in front of Honolulu. Not much shade from the few trees. A few picnic tables. Nothing magic happens here. Really not worth going to unless there is an outdoor festival or something planned. It's a great place for the festivals that happen because a lot of people can...


More  



me and my husband celebrated our silver wedding anniversary by renewing our vows here. the park is large and the beach is lovely.

The wife and I renewed our vows when we were here when we went on our anniversary trip this year. Beautiful place

Great place to visit, family friendly. Shops everywhere you turn. Restaurants too many to count. You can snorkel, paddle board, paddle boat or rent a chair and umbrella and just chill on the beach.

Magic Island is a quite nice park to stroll through at the western end of Waikiki a walking distance from Ilikai, and Hilton Village, If you come in the afternoon you get impressed with number of wedding couples taking pictures in this beautiful park There were 5 couples simultaneously being taken pictures of when I arrived. From the park you...


More  



A great spot for pictures but be there before dark. We walked from our hotel a few blocks away and got there just as the sun was setting and got a few pics. The homeless population in Hawaii is very prevalent around this area and even though we did not feel unsafe, it made us feel like we shouldn't have...


More  



I saw Magic Island from my hotel balcony and decided to walk there. It was definitely worth the walk. It was beautiful, patrolled, fairly unpopulated compared to other Waikiki beaches. The park was awesome with plenty of places to play ball or frisbee or simply relax. I didn't check out the restrooms but they were available. And one of the...


More  



A part of Ala Moana Beach Park, it is very popular with locals, you will stick out like a sore thumb.
Really like it for my early morning runs and to watch the sunsets here and the Friday night fireworks at the Hilton across Ala Wai harbour.
Also good place for swimming, fishing, snorkelling , surfing and spear fishing.

Best beach in Honolulu. So under rated. I tell everyone to go there and no one does! It's quiet, beautiful swimming, picnic tables, shade....everything!!

title: Pacific Aviation Museum Pearl Harbor, Honolulu
address: 319 Lexington Blvd, Historic Ford Island, Honolulu, Oahu, HI 96818
review_list:
I loved to see all the airplanes and see the aviation history of the Pacific side of WWII. The displays were very nice and each display and cool information on the particular aircraft.

I am a charter member of the PAMPH and I visit the museum every time I visit Hawaii which is every two years. The museum is a continuing work in progress and is doing an outstanding job of preserving Pacific aviation history, particularly WWII. It's education program is significant and also growing. Be sure to view the short film before...


More  



We weren't sure what we were going to see, but we were glad we did! A very good history of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbour and the subsequent naval and island actions.
The hangar was fantastic, being able to get "up close and personal" with so many different airplanes. Loved it and will be back.

While not the biggest US aviation museum, it was very well done. The wide range of airplanes, and super-committed docents, have me want to return. There 1 1/2 hours. Could have used more time and I'm anything but an airplane history buff.

We had a great time here. There are plenty of planes and other artifacts to make the trip enjoyable.

It was a great experience. If you have time, there are two hanger bays that you can walk through. The first hanger goes through everything that happened from the attack on Pearl through the conflict during WWII. The other hanger has planes and helicopters through current day military. Very educational.

While this museum does contain some very interesting pieces, it seemed expensive for the size and effort to get there. It is one of the stops on the bus trip over to Ford Island and the USS Missouri. For an additional fee, you can take a tour of a second hanger where they are restoring more pieces, but we did...


More  



I first visited the museum 4 years ago and was pleased to see it is becoming more known and visited. I like this museum because it is still "raw. ". You can see windows shot out in 1941 and bullet holes. The displays are well done. My favorite is the Niihau pilot story. You really are up close and personal...


More  



Must be booked through Pearl Harbour, You must go on a tour as it is on an active military base, cant take your own car. Bus shuttles leave and return every 15 mins, You can stay as long as you like and just jump on a shuttle when you are ready, Closes at 17.00pm

You'd think that an air museum at Pearl would be great, but this was the least impressive aviation museum I've been to. Extremely limited number of WW II era planes. Minimal exhibits. Skip it - it's a waste of time.

title: Ala Moana Beach Park, Honolulu
address: 1201 Ala Moana Blvd, Honolulu, Oahu, HI 96814
review_list:
Couldn't believe how NOT crowded the beach and park were. The place is quite big too. Take a nice long walk on the beach or down the walking path. Stop and sit on one of the many benches under the palm trees and enjoy the surf. One of the things we did was try to identify locations in the Park...


More  



This beach has a lot of good shade if necessary, a kiosk which sells alcohol and a couple of good cheap food outlets. Eastern end has coral and rock bottom. Middle section is great.

Nice beach, away from the hustle and bustle of Waikiki and its tourist crowd. Not to say, there isn't much to do. On the contrary, there is so much activity including paddle boarding, surfing, swimming, or simply laying under the sun.

Nice beach, very clean and away from the tourist crowd of Waikiki. Lots of shades and picnic tables. Also a great place for walking or jogging. The beach is a huge and very calm, perfect for lounging around, kids and family friendly. Lots of parking, but it does gets very crowded in the weekend. Shower and bathroom facilities are clean,...


More  



If you can get past off the homeless people laying in the park, the beach is very nice. They do have areas to picnic and BBQing. They do have public restrooms.

There are many other beaches in O'ahu that are way more interesting and relaxing than Ala Moana. Have to admin for some people this might be a better alternative than Waikiki Beach.

I live across the street from the beach. I see sunset almost every evening. It's a good place for kayaking, stand up paddling, surfing and even parasailing. You can take good pictures of sunset. Park is a nice place to sit down, watch the waves of the calm ocean and relax.

there is nothing spectacular or special about the beach here - more locals than Waikiki which is nice - no tWaikiki - which is nice.

This beach is more beautiful than Waikiki beach. It is also free parking, areas for BBQ, showers and toilets. It is much quieter than the busy Waikiki beach.Very short walking distance from the Ala Moana shopping centre with loads of shops and restaurants.

Its a fairly large park by the beach - its nice and quiet compared to the rest of Wakiki, and its ideal for runners.

title: Kapiolani Park, Honolulu
review_list:
Pretty cool park, Nothing insane about it. Lots of shade to escape the hot hawaii sun. Worth a check out.

Tired of walking the shopping streets of Wakaki? Fed up with the beach crowd scene? Then follow the easy accessible walk to this park. Not crowded, shady with grass and picnic tables. Great space without interruption to view the Pacific

We loved our walk to Kapiolani Park from our hotel at the other end of Waikiki Beach. There were great views of the water, surfing lessons, the reef wave break, and the gorgeous old trees. There were various easy smooth walking paths to choose from. Many people were out enjoying the park and there was even a Framer's market going...


More  



Nice park area with lots of birds, close to Waikiki Beach.
Keep an eye out for the Green Parakeets, best seen at dusk.

One of my favorite activities in Waikiki is a long walk along the beach through the Kapiolani park. The sound and smell of ocean water, the ocean breeze, the warm sun, all the tropical plants, particularly the Banyan tree with its prop roots and over arching branches,the bright Bougainvillia bush, row of Casuarina trees along the road all make it...


More  



This part was pretty well used while we were here. However,there appear to be a lot of homeless people living in and around the park. Most do not bother you a bit. Appears to be a gathering place for local families to have birthday parties, etc. Right across from the beach if you need to get out of the sun.

On Sundays the Hawaii State Band plays free concerts in the park. It is a simple walk from your hotel. They also play at the Iolani Palace during the week.
This is a large park.

We were staying at the Outrigger on the Beach and decided to take a walk towards Diamonhead. We walked on the sidewalk side to do some people watching and not have to walk in the sand. We ended up walking down into Kapiolani Park. We stayed on the sidewalk the entire time passing several beaches and jetties. It's apparent the...


More  



Lovely park to get away from the sun. Stroll amongst the trees, enjoy the view. Have a panic or take a book to read and relax in the shade.

Family neighborhoods surround the park. It us a great spot to stroll and take in the kids playing, etc. You can hear the parrots that reside there nibbling and socializing on top of the tropical fruit trees. Great place to get away from city noise.

title: Ala Moana Center, Honolulu
address: 1450 Ala Moana Boulevard, Honolulu, Oahu, HI 96814
review_list:
We spent a full day here.
There are many shops to look at. It also has Macy's and Nordstrom.
The Lego store is also popular for kids.
The food court offers different cuisines.
The restroom facilities are clean and plentiful.
Some areas are open and others are under cover.
If you're in a mood for some retail therapy this is...


More  



We spent quite some time in this place. It's huge. Don't expect great deals or discounts as most is high end shopping.
Some of the sales people become a little too intrusive by trying to get you into the shops and being quite rude when you say that you're not interested.
However, the food court is great. Every type of...


More  



This location was close to our hotel and gave us plenty of options for more affordable fair within 5 minutes. Honolulu is definitely a shopping destination but not what we planned our trip around.

Ok to take kids in the stroller, lots of places to eat cheap to mid range. Lots of shops, there are shades, places to seat and rest. You can take the bus, you can take the trolley, taxi, lots of parking. Lots of brand name shops. There's a big disney store for kids. You cna easliy spend 2 hrs in...


More  



Being one of the shuttle stops from our hotel (The Kahala), my wife and I decided to check out this mall. We were pleasantly surprised to find all of the stores we would normally have on the mainland in addition to several ABC's. The food court was large and had a variety of options to choose from. Weather can affect...


More  



I'm always a bit suprised when I see this centre reviewed so glowingly. Certainly, it's a very large centre with many stores and the fact that it's also an "outdoor" mall probably adds to its appeal. However I have visited this centre on two separate trips and neither left me terribly impressed! Perhaps this is because I come from Melbourne,...


More  



A
The Center has undergone major changes bringing international branded companies but Long's continues to go strong. High end is Ala Moana. The food court has undergone a major renovation over time and increased the variety of offerings.

As a local who live here, Ala Moana Center is the biggest and also the number one shopping mall in Honolulu. The big department stores like Macy's, Nordstrom, Neiman Marcus and Bloomingdale's are here. Everything you want could be found here. I do my shopping here.

We went to this mall on a day trip to Oahu. We had not been there since part of the new wing opened and we wanted to go to Bloomingdales. The shopping center is way better than it was before! Only half of the new wing is open so we will be back when the rest if it opens.....I love...


More  



If you want to go shopping in Honolulu, then the Ala Moana is a must. Its very clean, pleasant with a great range of shops and restaurants.

title: Oahu Diving, Honolulu
address: Kewalo Basin Harbor, 1009 Ala Moana Blvd, Honolulu, Oahu, HI 96825
review_list:
Great experience as a 1st time scuba diver. The 2 dives make it worthwhile. Friendly team to assist from A to Z. Pictures provided in the cost an added bonus and memory of the trip.

Erik was awesome! He put together a last minute dive for us..oganized and easy to deal with. By far the best part of our trip so far! We saw lots of marine life and are looking forward to the great photos! Shout out to Tyler for all the help with the rookies!

This is a great company to go out with on your first diving experience. Erik gives you a thorough tutorial on land before getting on the boat and getting ready. Once you're in the water, Tyler and him check in with you constantly to make sure you're feeling OK and if you're nerves get the better of you (like they...


More  



We had a great time diving with Oahu Diving!! It was a first time experience for most of our group and we were all thrilled with it! Eric was very thorough in his instructions, presented the material in a manner that was friendly and easily understood. He was very patient and made sure we were safe at all times. We...


More  



I was a little apprehensive about diving for the first time, but Erik made the experience so easy and enjoyable! He took wonderful underwater photos and had a great eye for spotting awesome sea turtles and octopus that are hidden amongest the coral reefs!

I admit, although it was scary at first, staff was super friendly and supportive. They made sure we knew clearly how to first to clear our masks and breathers before fully taking us in, and guided us throughout the dive! Maria was very knowledgeable of the area, and took us to areas not known by others. Maria was very accommodating to all our needs and gave us all helpful tips for great quality photos. I'd highly recommend Blue Hawaii!

Our tour guide/teacher is Jim who was great at bringing us to beautiful spots for our sunrise tour. He taught me to bracket my photos to see what combinations are better. This was a lovely way to spend an afternoon . Learnt some new tricks about using my dslr and got to see some beautiful parts of Oahu. Loved the small group tour . Great variety of places to take photos .

I went on the Hawaii Jeep Tour yesterday with my family and it was fantastic. This is a must do if you are on Oahu. They use all local drivers who know the island and the history of Hawaii. Beau was an amazing driver. He took us to all the best spots and brought us to places the big tour...

This might have been the best time spent of our week in Honolulu. Our driver was Sean and he is truly talented, personable, and so well informed. He knows where to go, how to get there, and he has a great sense of what you will appreciate and enjoy.

Best day ever! Amy was awesome! All the sites were great. Great info. Very knowledgable. The video presentations were excellent and Susie at bayer estate rocks!
Love love love
Will do it again. Will refer everyone I know! Thanks again!

We try Jeep Tours in Honolulu Vacation trip --so exited moment .
Hawaiian Nature and Jungle where we drive sample Beautiful , and a lot of Fun . Fun.Fun.

If you want to avoid long lines and enjoy each new experience, then choose Hawaii Jeep Tours for a wonderful time.
