title: Puu Ualakaa State Park, Honolulu
address: Round Top Drive, Honolulu, Oahu, HI
review_list:
You've got your rental car and a list of places to visit around the island. Make sure Puu Ualakaa is on it. The twisting drive through forest and past ocean view homes will bring you out on breathtaking overlook, with a complete panorama of South Oahu. It's popular at sunset which can challenge the small lot, and make the twisty...


More  



We drove up Round Top Drive, stopped at the overlook of the city for some great views, had a picnic lunch in the park, then continued down Tantalus Drive and into the Punch Bowl . This was a very nice outing in amongst some beautiful trees, some great views, the park has a couple of covered picnic areas well maintained...


More  



Do NOT leave valuables in your car. Two cars were immediately broken into just before we arrived, the second incident that day.

I had lunch from here Feb. 10. The view was spectacular. My city tour came drove us here from Waikiki Beach. The entertainment was awesome.

Aside from the awesome panoramic views of Honolulu at the adjacent lookout, this is also a quiet small park with two picnic table. It was not crowded both times we stopped there. Both tables were available. Short walk to lookout past the restrooms. Quiet park. Well maintained. Police security there on one stop.

Traveled up, up, up to Puu Ualakaa Park via the Tantalus route, a snaking-back-and-forth drive through a lush forest-y area. Encountered several tourist shuttle vans on the way up, which confirmed we must be on our way to a noteworthy place :-) While marveling at the gorgeous views of Honolulu and all the way to Diamond Head in the far...


More  



i had fun riding my bike up there. great view and theres lots of trails you can hike to. theres also a tree house if you look for it and it has a nice view too. they used to have swing but they took it away..

Took the Tantalus drive up which was relaxing and quiet. Think 180 hairpins covered by old growth trees and gorgeous vegetation with hardly any traffic. The actual park is clean and quiet. I was there midweek and it was basically empty. I didn't picnic or hike here but checked out the overlook. An incredible view of Honolulu and Diamond Head....


More  



We visited this State Park as part of a private tour. A drive up the mountain, winding roads, but beautiful scenery on the way. Once you get to the top, WOW......spectacular. Great photo opportunity here with this gorgeous overall view. Go and check it out!!

We were doing the Tantulus/Roundtop Dr. As we were coming down from the Tantulus side we ran into the Puu Ualkaa State Park. Following Oahu Revealed instructions we took the 2 lefts at the intersections and ended at a great viewpoint! Wow! What an overlook! You can see about 1/2 of the island!
Go see it! Well worth the drive!

title: Kuhio Beach Park, Honolulu
review_list:
During this time of the year, there were a lot of people taking advantage of the sun and surf. The water was pristine and a had beautiful shades of various blue colors. Pictures didn't do it justice!

At the end of Waikiki is a memorable beach protected by a jetty. It has a grassy area and beautiful soft sand sand so you can take your pick. Check out the early evening schedule they often have free music concerts and hula. Popular with locals.

Or great just for a walk as the walk up the beach towards the shell is spectacular and relaxing. Good place to watch the beach basketball or just lie in the sand!

A nice stroll along the beach path, you will see all walks of life.
They provide a hula show on Saturday nights here for free which is a plus.
It's always busy and buzzing with events.
Great place to watch the sunset around 6pm.
You can grab a snack and sit here and enjoy the atmosphere

An amazing place to sit and watch the sunset, or to play in the water but before you go out to Dinner sit and watch the sunset, makes for an amazing evening

At the Diamond Head end of the Waikiki near the statue of Duke Kahanamoku and that large banyan tree. Relax in the park, picnic, sit and watch the people, surf, swim, and join the crowds. Lots of food places nearby and catch the torch lighting, hula dancing and singing.

The place to be. Whether it's to swim, stroll,sit and read a book, just a relaxing place. Lots to see. A wonderful place to catch a show, the torch lighting, music, hula or the most beautiful sunset. We always go back.

A little gem in the middle of Waikiki. on the Diamond Head end of the beach and a very chill place. You can pick up some :Plate Lunch" at a local eatery, and make a picnic on the beach, plenty of picnic tables too, if you prefer not to eat sand :)

The beach is located direct behind the Kalakaua Ave and is a public ocean-side park near the zoo. During the day it is a bit crowded and closes at 11p.m. You can rent a surf board here if you want or just strolling along the Waikiki Wall which reach about 50m into the water. You also can walk from this...


More  



It's Waikiki beach so very busy, not really my thing personally. Over crowded and bouts pretty much sums it up. For all of you wanting to learn to surf do not book on line. Online is way more money and there are so many places to get lessons and way cheaper it's 60 dollars max and if you want a...


More

title: Statue of Duke Kahanamoku, Honolulu
review_list:
Located on the Waikiki "promenade " a beautiful large statue commemorating his exploits is worth a short stop.

Somehow at night, with leis around his neck and the spotlights highlighting the statue, you "feel" his legacy. Then with the surf noise in the back, the board rental places just feet away, you have to think he must be smiling back.

The statue overlooks Waikiki beach so you can't miss it if you're walking along the promenade. One of several similar statues in Honolulu they are a traditional part of the island.

An iconic landmark that beckons you to have your photo taken with it. Bring a lei and keep it looking good for other travelers. There is almost always a group of folks taking pictures in front of it, I would definitely recommend taking the walk, to have your picture taken with the Duke. It is even better if you did...


More  



great place to have your photo taken on waikiki! the statue is normally wearing various leis that tourist adorn it with. The statue is very tall and really stands out.

If in Hawaii it's a must next to the legendary Duke. Particularly at sunset when the colours in the background really finish off a great photo!

The grand-father of modern surfing. Pay your homage to this great man while you visit Waikiki. If you are surfer this is a must in Honolulu.

The waves were nice and the park was clean. My wife walk from the Hilton Hawaiian gardens to this park. It had the normal rentals and people taking selfies. We both enjoyed the beach and the sound of the waves.

It's nice that Hawaii recognizes the father of competitive surfing. It was neat that people would bring their leiis from their luau to his statue and lay them at his feet. It was a great tribute.

AS we were walking down coast, we came upon this statue of Duke. We stop took pics and read the little bio that was at the foot of Duke. The views of the beach behind the statue are great.

title: Aloha Stadium Swap Meet, Honolulu
address: 99-500 Salt Lake Blvd, Honolulu, Oahu, HI 96818
review_list:
If you see something in a shop that you think you might want to buy to take home to friends, wait and go here. TONS of shops, all selling some of the same things. Great prices and you can bargain. There is some cheap stuff but some of it is just the same as you can find anywhere else.
Oh...


More  



The Flea market/Swap meet at the stadium is huge and wraps itself around the stadium car park. As a visitor to the Island was stunned at just how big this was. It was a great chance to try local food, find a memento of our visit to Honolulu and we spent longer there than had planned. Just so much to...


More  



The weather forecast was cloudy and cool. The best part of the whole day was the bus ride from Ala Moana. The driver was a comic and we got off the bus doubled over laughing. The market was full of low priced T shirts and trinkets and expensive dust collectors. An interesting aspect was some carvers practicing traditional wood carving...


More  



We were traveling with our parents who have to souvenir shop. They love the fact that they could spend hours and hours going to different booths and talking to different people and get great deals. If you're a t-shirt shopper there are deals for 70 shirts for $20 with hundreds of designs for selection period and unique hand carved items...


More  



I hadn't been here in 6 years. It use to be a jam packed event, but it's down to about a third of its original size. There are few real "local" vendors any more. They all seem to be supplied by the same distributors that supply the ABC stores in waikiki. Yes if you're looking for cheap silk screened 7...


More  



You can find almost every type of souvenirs here, from spices to shirts. Best price compare to any place in oahu for souvenirs. It is hot, dress appropriately. Have nice comfortable foot wear, bring a hat, sunscreen, sunglasses, iced water. Bring cash. A huge tote bag to carry your purchases. Theres tons of parking, come early around 8 or 9....


More  



Go here for souvenirs, its cheap and lots of variety like t-shirts, native crafts, beach towels and everything else. There are also local fruits and foods. This is a must for the tourists.

We spent about two hours here going through the many, many booths. Admission is $1/person and is worth it just to see the many items for sale ranging from crafts to food to inexpensive souvenirs.

This is where you should buy all your souvenirs. My one regret is I didn't bring enough cash to buy some of the goods that Waikiki stores are selling for double and triple the prices. If you are also looking for silk flowers for your hair, come here, there was one lady who makes the most gorgeous flowers. I bought...


More  



We spent a week in Hawaii and went to the swap meet twice. This is the place to go and purchase all your souvenirs. Extremely cheep prices on the stuff you will find in every gift shop.
The venue is quite large, however the shops seem to be the same. Walk in either direction for 10 minutes and you've seen...


More

title: Royal Hawaiian Center, Honolulu
review_list:
We stayed close by to the Royal Hawaiian Centre.
There are many stores/shops here. Also there are restaurants and also a food court.
There is always events held at the centre stage. From hula shows to artists singing local songs. They also offer free hula classes to lei making.
This area also shortcuts to many hotels in the area.

They have restored this beautifully with lots of outside areas. There is a range of entertainment available through the day, entirely free and it's a lovely place to stop in. The food court has a range of options for all budgets, which you can then take out into the garden area and watch the shows. Great local music and dance...


More  



A beautiful place to visit with many photo opportunities in the Hawaiian garden where you can also sit to eat your lunch on bench seats. There is an upstairs food court which has a good variety of different cuisines to please all kinds of taste buds at good prices. Upmarket shops on 2 levels surround this amazing complex. Definitely worth...


More  



This is a beautiful mall. Redone a few years ago in such a tasteful way. It's so pleasant to visit the central garden where they host shows and exhibits. See it at night-magical. The mall is several levels with mostly high end stores. Top floor seemed to be mostly some enticing looking fine dining. But there's a good food court...


More  



The food court is an unexpected find for those on a budget. We had delicious and huge $10 lunches at Panda Express (Chinese) and $13 pizza's. The food court setting is also very pleasant, in a covered outdoor setting, clean and has a great atmosphere.

All the high end shopping experiences you could want are under one long three storied shopping building. The place is alive with shoppers from early morning till 11PM. The choices of food in the food court is very good and always busy.People are shopping, eating and browsing at All hours.

This place has everything:
1) restaurants and a food court 2) shopping (all sorts of brands and stores) 3) nightly entertainment (hula dancing, singers, shows) 4) cultural classes during the day (lei making, hula classes, quilt making, ukele, etc)
This place is very large...3-4 blocks long. Love the torches at night time :)
Every night in Waikiki we always end...


More  



Went to eat here a few times and found the found the food very good and reasonably priced.we bought a huge pizza for $13 and couldnt eat it all huge variations of foods in the food court.. Most of the shops were empty and so we walked around and enjoyed the gardens and loved the torches down the streets.

Great variety of stores from carts to entry level to high end fashion and retail. Very very picturesque exterior, beautiful gardens. Very nice restaurant area.

Went here late afternoon on a Monday. Ate at The Cheesecake Factory and then walked off the calories by visiting several stores including Crazy shirts and Honolulu ookie company.

title: Don Quijote, Honolulu
review_list:
This is a very unique Japanese super market from Japan. Many local food products as well as Asian ingredients. They have favorite local souvenirs, Mac nuts, cookies, coffees as well as a fully cooked deli. The ahi is great as well as sashimi selections.

I love this place! So many options to pick from, ready to eat, or cook at home items. My daughter loves all the treats and snacks. I can always find things to send to friends and family around

Yes, Spam. It's not normally on our list of favorites, but we on a quest. We were on the hunt shopping around the island in search of Garlic flavored Spam for a relative back home. We checked all the shopping centers on Oahu for days with no luck until a local tipped us off and directed us to Don's where...


More  



This place is something else I feel like I'm in another world They have unique items plus the fast food stands out front are awesome. We are staying in a condo nearby for the winter and this our go to place for everything

Stocked up on a few things down the street at Walmart but their produce section is pitiful. Followed the locals 2 blocks from Walmart and found this gem of a store.

This was an interesting little find in our explorations. We like to go to grocery stores when we travel, and this was a good one! I recommend going in, even if just for a look!

They have so many things you will see nowhere else. Also great fruits and veggies . A really fun place to shop.

Our first thanksgiving dinner, email contact with Liza enabled us to organize to order cooked meal online( though it was past the cut off date) and we were helped and welcomed by Kitty!!! SUCH GREAT CUSTOMER SERVICE, this is why us Aussies love coming to Hawaii!!!!!!

I thought Don Quijote only exist in Japan but I was wrong! I was really excited to find one in Honolulu. It's like a Japanese version of Walmart but Its got a better selection of Asian products with great price AND it's open 24 hours! I find the macadamia nut chocolates here are cheaper than Walmart. I always buy all...


More  



Saw this online before we travelled. It was much better than expected. The souvenir section is awesome! You have to watch for their weekly ads and sales an fetch a great bargain. Huge selection of a lot of items. We were so glad we found this place. Definitely a great place to shop while in Honolulu.

title: King Kamehameha Statue, Honolulu
address: 417 South King Street Honolulu, Honolulu, Oahu, HI HI 96813
review_list:
If you are familiar with Hawaii Five-O you will recognize this statue right away. I don't think anyone will think you missed out if you don't see it, but it is an icon and worth a visit.

While there, the spot immediately in front of the statute was packed with so many Japanese tourists getting their group pictures that I could I had trouble getting a clear photo. So those groups jostling became the photo opportunity. Then I took in the beautiful courthouse directly behind the statue. Fortuitous. Snapped shots of the palace (across the street but...


More  



It is a must see if you are a lover of the Hawaii 5 0 series. It was well maintained albeit a bit trick to find.

There's not much to take in, but it's a good place to include your mug in a selfie. Everyone will know where you were. Doesn't scratch the surface of Hawaian history.

When you go to Honolulu, you should go to see the King. " He" is beautiful but there is also great history behind King Kamehameha. The architecture of the courthouse and the surrounding building were very pretty.

Like many of you my first view of the statue was on the Hawaii Five-0 television opening scenes. It was a special feeling to see it in person. It is not as tall as I was expecting it to be, but still quite impressive.
The history behind it is what fascinates me most. The American sculptor Thomas R. Gould was...


More  



The statue is nice to look at but that is all there is to it. This is also a replica, not the original statue. Go on King Kamehameha Day and it will be decked out in leis otherwise it is just a statue of the first king of the United Hawaii.

After being fans of the old "Hawaii 50" TV series it put this in perspective after all these years when we first saw it years ago and still check it out whenever we visit Hawaii each year. It is a beautiful statue and I think anyone that has seen either the old or new Hawaii 50 TV series should enjoy...


More

lovely statue but not much else you can say about it. Well worth the photo stop if you can find parking.

title: Honolulu Zoo, Honolulu
review_list:
Nothing special about this zoo compared to others. My favorite part was the 2 orangutans cuddling under a blanket. It was cute. Worth every penny though to go. A fun activity.

Expensive entry.

I like the lions but they must been at the vet..........so I never saw them. I really like the different plants in this Zoo.

After viewing the sunrise at Diamond Head Crater we went looking for an eclectic breakfast at the KCC Farmer's Market. Well, it was sure not what I expected of a farmer's market. After the sunrise at Diamond Head we visited the Farmer's Market KCC.
You can find a little bit of everything, fresh fruits, ice cream, honey, jams, butters, bread, cookies, etc.
You can also buy food ready to eat.

My girlfriends and I rented an Airbnb house and the owner recommended we visit the farmer's market which was just a 5 minute drive from our place. It was a nice local activity to do with lots of food and things to just look at. Worth coming for a visit.

It has been a while since our last trip to the KCC Saturday Farmer's Market but we went back this month to check out what's new. Never boring, we saw old vendors as well as new and interesting ones! As usual, it was crowded. Will go back again for sure and next time, we'll take our time and enjoy the...

I guess I was hoping for a bigger variety of local crafts, arts, and maybe music . It was all food. The farmer's market in King's Village and on the corner of Kapahulu is just as good , if not better. I was going out that way anyways, in search of the Thrift shop at the hospital ( which is...

After climbing Diamond Head on Saturday we headed over to the KCC to look around and ended up having a great breakfast. Made the climb that much better.

I went at 9:30 am and was still able to find a parking spot fairly quickly, although the road getting into the parking lot was a mess. The market was very crowded and there were only a few fresh fruit/vegetable vendors. I had been hoping for more, but perhaps it's the wrong season. If you're looking to try foods, this...

There was a lot of things here to see and buy, some of the stuff was flea market stuff, but there were a lot of cool things too, Lot's of local fruit

Small market located near Diamond Head. The market comprises a number of local food stalls and a mixed bag of other vendors including fresh fruit and vegetables. Worth a thirty minute walk around but be aware it is only small and very local. If you are taking the bus be aware that they only run every hour and will fill...

title: Waikiki Aquarium, Honolulu
address: 2777 Kalakaua Avenue, Waikiki, Honolulu, Oahu, HI 96815
review_list:
great place to visit , only small to some other aquariums but they only charge a small amount. they do have a seal lion and a seal that most other aquariums don't

I call this my 15 minute aquarium, that is all you need to see the whole thing. For a tropical island you would think we would have something more robust. For the price of admission this aquarium just doesn't deliver.

I've always loved aquariums. This one was charming. Great exhibits of coral reefs and they had two monk seals - beautiful creatures. We got there at feeding and training time and it was a treat to watch them. Good way to spend a couple of hours inside and learn about sea creatures.

We walked to the aquarium after watching guys surf. It was fun and I had a coupon for it. My family enjoyed it. Most of the tanks are inside and a few things are outside. Don't remember excessive walking except to get there. Beautiful parks and shoreline are right there close to the Aquarium. I took bus ride back to...


More  



With all the natural beauty Oahu has there is little or no need to visit the aquarium. The fish seemed cramped in their tanks and the whole place was very small, the seals were cute but that's really the only nice thing I can say about it. Entry is expensive for what it is.

Outdoor exhibit with a sea lion or two and a small tidal pool. Inside, lots of small tanks with themed exhibits, including sea horses.

Nice little aquarium, the exibits were well set up and the portable information system explains each exhibit clearly. The students who give the demonstrations with the monk seals are knowledgeable andhelpful and good with youngsters with lots of questions.

We went to Waikiki aquarium for a luau. Included in the luau price was free entrance to the aquarium itself. It is a beautiful place, well worth a visit when in Honolulu.

I'm 20 and studying biology and marine science, so I had a great time here looking at all the fish and reading all the information, it was very interesting! Not bad for a small aquarium, and an easy way to kill an hour or two :)

This aquarium is a short walk along the beachfront towards Diamond Head. make Sure your headphone works ( this aspect could be managed better ) before you start then enjoy! The coral and reef fish displays are fantastic. They have a magnificent giant clam...everyone including myself was amazed by this clam. You Will see Live nautilus and other exhibits not...

title: Lyon Arboretum, Honolulu
address: 3860 Manoa Rd., University of Hawaii-Manoa, Honolulu, Oahu, HI 96822
review_list:
Simply must enjoy the splendor of a rain forest while in Hawaii and Lyon Arboretum is just the place to be overwhelmed with peace and beauty. Just off the Pali above University of Hawaii, it is easy to get to. You'll be walking so think of footwear with traction.

The Manoa Valley setting for the Arboretum is stunning. The Hawaiian Ethnobotanical garden is particularly interesting. A great place for a relaxing walk.

Even though we went soon after a rain fall we still had a nice hike but at times slippery. Make sure you have hiking shoes on or at least sneakers. About a half day trip.

Beautiful flowers, and very nice gardens laid out. I didn't have time to explore them all, but what I did, was fabulous.

Take a stroll in an authentic Hawaiian Rain Forest full of local flowers, trees and birds. Well maintained by UH Manoa for the public to enjoy the natural beauties of our island. Just across the valley from where I have lied 32 years. Each visit is a treat! Often have amazing plant/orchid sales there.

Lyon Arboretum is situated at the end of a winding road behind Honolulu, in the Manoa Valley, an extension of the University of Hawaii, it has the charter to conserve, curate and study native Hawaiian plants, and the increase the appreciation of the unique flora of Hawaii.
Very pleasant to walk the many trails in the 200 acres, some quite...


More  



The arboretum has decent trails that you can hike even when it is raining. There are some interesting plants and a small waterfall to see.

We did an hour long walk thru and it is superb. MUCH better than Manoa Falls, which is really crowded with very limited views. Wear good shoes and take bug spray. Allow for 3 hours to really enjoy it.

Combined this with the Moana Falls hike, actually enjoyed this better.
Offered a pleasant, serene brake from the masses of tourists.
Give yourself plenty of time to explore the many side trails.
This is more for true trekking and nature lovers.
Wear trekking shoes and mosquito repellant (although the mosquitos were not too bad)

Best place in Hawaii to k ow the plants and nature. If you are interested in gardens, plants and nature this is the best place. This is good for a hike too that give a oder ate exercise. Entry and parking is free and they accept donations. If you are a botanist or wanting more details about th e plants...

title: USS Oklahoma Memorial, Honolulu
address: Ford Island, Pearl Harbor, Honolulu, Oahu, HI
review_list:
War is ghastly, but of all of the tragic stories of Pearl Harbor, the saddest is the Oklahoma. 400 men trapped below decks when the battleship capsized and flooded the compartments. Rescue crews struggled to cut their way through to reach the crew desperately tapping on the hull with wrenches. Only a very few were saved. Something we need to...


More  



You can see influences in this style of memorial, from the concept at the Oklahoma bombing site and Vietnam memorial site in DC. Reading the plaques, taking in the meaning of the memorial is worth the short time it takes when they all gave their lives.

This memorial is wonderful and, if it wasn't for the bus driver, I would have missed it! It's almost a secret on Ford Island. I think it needs to be more prominently promoted.

We had a tour to the 4 stops in Pearl Harbor. Enjoyed the history and walking around seeing and feeling what veterans did while onboard.

Located away from the Arizona Memorial it is possibly less visited, and overshadowed by the battleship moored across the car park. Never-the-less the memorial is well designed depicting the crew of the Oklahoma at attention, a tribute to those that died during the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbour. Make time during your visit to pay your respects.

while out seeing the sights of Oahu we viewed this memorial to the USS Oklahoma and her crew. Sad and somber moments thinking of all who died here on that day. Historic sights of our Nations history

This is at the same time really sad, and beautiful. If you have not been here you should go. I have to say though that it was really sad. Totally worth going. Definitely make a point and go. This place is a part of our history and I wish for all wars to stop immediately. When you are here you...


More  



A smaller but no less important than the memorial than the Arizona. This memorial is on land since the Oklahoma was refloated in 1943 and returned to the mainland.
The easiest way to visit this location is to take the shuttle bus from the Arizona to the Missouri and then walk.

If you miss the opportunity of seeing this it will be such a shame, but it wise to take a tissue, not make that a box.

Located on Ford Island, adjacent to the USS Missouri. Most tourists will need to visit this site and other Ford Island sites including the Pacific Aviation Museum as part of a Group Tour. The reason for this is that Ford Island remains an active part of the Pearl Harbor Naval Base.
As a Retired US Navy Sailor and Current NOAA...

title: Waikiki Beach Walk, Honolulu
address: Lewers Street, Between Kalakaua Avenue & Kalia Road, Honolulu, Oahu, HI
review_list:
Great walk through the park and along the beach front. Very relaxing and nice way to start your morning.

We spent a few evenings walk into stores tasting different foods and enjoying the scenery great place to check out.

Be a tourist even if it feels wrong, Go wet your feet, come back Friday night and see the Fireworks; even better visit prior to sunset.

Great to get out and stretch your legs. If you go early in the morning it isn't crowded and the views are spectacular.

Busy street for resturants and shops ,The Yard House , Cheeseburger in Paradise ,ABC STORE , Dennys'

in the heart of Waikiki - a revamped street with new hotels and shopping district, and places to eat - worth a visit

The Beach Walk is a collection of shops and restaurants. There is an area in front of the shops that features a grassy area & fountain where at times there is Hawaiian entertainment including music & hula dancing. The shops feature artists from Hawaii. This is a place to shop & eat that I can afford, with beautiful surroundings.

Had a great walk along the Waikiki Beach and the swim in the beach was a lovely way to spend every morning doing.

Great walk, lots of people around, cafes' and shops. The beach was great and the people are friendly

title: Moanalua Gardens Park, Honolulu
review_list:
I stopped by here for a couple photos of the "Hitachi Tree". It is one of several monkey pod trees in the park and was used as the Hitachi logo. The park is not worth a spicial trip to see, but if you're driving by on the H201 freeway - stop and check it out.

Nice clean park to lay out a picnic blanket or just laze and read a book. Lots of shade and grass and not busy at all.

I lived near the garden for 2 months, I would go for walks everyday there. the air is so fresh, the scenery is so breathe taking, I truly enjoyed walking here. My granddaughter was able to just run and have fun in the grass and have fun. I can't wait to visit here on my next visit.

We love going to Moanalualani Gardens for the peace and beauty. Hard to believe that the freeway is right there, bit within a few moments, the trees, the plants begin to transport you to another time. We especially love going during the Prince Lot Hula Festival. Sitting under the magnificent great canopy of the monkey pod trees, listening to the...

Spent the day relaxing at the gardens watching the fish in the ponds and enjoying the peace and quite.

big open green spaces. Magnificent old trees to picnic under. Streams run through and lovely foliage to look through

Plenty of space and different gardens. Nice trails for running and right in the middle of everything!

The Moanalua Gardens is a 26 acre public garden with a taro patch and Koi pond....
There is a stream that flows through the gardens and a circular path that you can walk that crosses over the stream a couple of times.
The Gardens is the home to the Prince Lot Hula Festival which is held on a weekend each...


More  



If you want to know how it really feels to be in paradise this is the spot. Quiet beauty, lush plants surrounds me with beauty that you can't find at many places. The park is gorgeous.

title: Kaimana Beach, Honolulu
review_list:
Meter park on Kalakua Blvd, (be careful to keep the meter fed), grab a plate lunch from one of the numerous purveyors, eat at one of the benches in the shaded grassy areas, and enjoy the clean caim water and the soft sand. Perfect for snorkeling. No wonder it is so popular with locals, but still Uncrowded.

Great place to parf affordable and to watch the friday 19;45 Hilton fireworks each week. Great trees, close to Zoo, public bathrooms. Need change to park; ask hotel and the will give you a whole pack of quarters (in return for a 10 bill off course)

wonderful place to relax in the sun, read a book or newspaper or just watch the world go bye. Great place to bring picnic lunches, hang with friends. Parking is always a premium so come early or later in the afternoon.

Very nice beach to relax and dip in the water without fear of huge waves. Great for families with young children. Can get crowded especially on the weekends.

Love coming here because you can actually swim without huge waves wiping you out. It's a local gathering place so family oriented and easy going.

South of the aquarium . Not a lot is shade and can be windy. Quiet, not crowed yet only a 15 minute walk from Kuhio beach in Waikiki

Beautiful beach right across the Kapiolani park.It's wonderful for a lovely walk by the clear blue waters.

Bring your snorkel gear and underwater camera! You and NOT going to want to miss the marine life that will be swimming along side of you. Beautiful fish and small sea creatures. We were lucky enough to share the water with sea turtles!!! Priceless!!

I love this beach. Its mainly a local beach and dog beach. Its close to the Natatorium. Usually easy parking, and lifeguards and shower. At the hotel overlooking the beach there is a small convenience store for snacks etc. No shade! Bring an umbrella or walk to the grassy area by the showers and you will find benches and trees...

I have been coming to this beach for over 35 years. My keikis( children) went swimming here at this safe beach. The reef protects it from big waves, just right for the little ones. title: Foster Botanical Gardens, Honolulu
address: 50 North Vineyard Blvd., Honolulu, Oahu, HI 96817
review_list:
Who knew that in the midst of late afternoon going-home traffic you could find a pool of serenity in the heart of Honolulu, Foster Botanical Gardens. A natural, living museum of flora and fauna within the south Pacific Islands. Easily accessible by city bus or Wakaki Trolley. Reasonable admission ($3~$5) Opportunity for guided tour if you time it correctly. An oasis tucked within the city.

The gardens are not large and can be walked round in 40 mins or so.The specimen trees are numbered and named in the leaflet you are given when you enter [Ithis did't click till I was almost out]
There is a small shop but no food ,however the Chinese quarter is 5 minute walk away.
plenty of free parking

If you're interested in the flora of Hawaii, both indigenous and introduced, this is a good place to get an introduction to it. We went on a docent-led tour which was excellent. Our guide was very knowledgable and enthusiastic, and gave us a lot of information about the plants and their uses, as well as the history of the area...


More  



Can't say I was overly impressed with this place. Seems a little run down and not very much to see. Some cool old trees, but that's about it

In this midst of the business of Honolulu lies this amazing botanical garden. Do take the opportunity to visit! It is very quiet, peaceful and nature abounds in beauty. There is ample parking and definitely not expensive to visit. Go and enjoy the beauty, the scents, and if you stand real still you may even have one of the butterflies...


More  



What a bargain for $5! This is a wonderful spot on the edge of Chinatown. Some gigantic trees that are out of this world! And the greenhouse has beautiful orchids. Worth a visit.

Easily accessible on Vineyard Street near downtown Honolulu, this is one of the hidden treasures on our islands. Many of the indigenous plants and trees seen here are rare looks at Hawaii's flora of years gone by. Tranquil wonderful place to stroll in nature.

The gardens are modestly priced and if you plan ahead it is possible to have a complimentary tour with an experienced and knowledgeable botanist. A guide will explain the significance of some of the trees in the collection as well as connect the seeds displayed at the entrance of the gardens with the trees they come from. Give yourself a...

title: Queen Emma Summer Palace, Honolulu
review_list:
Beautiful setting. Small but interesting museum with easy parking. Can walk through the back to a large park.

We visited this palace with our three and five year old daughters. We would recommend avoiding bringing young children here, as the guided tours are more for adults interested in the history of Hawai'i and its people, rather than for children with short attention spans. The house and its contents are lovingly preserved and children have a tendency to want...


More  



A small cottage packed with personal items from the royal family. In particular there are several Royal garments made from bird feathers. One robe required over one million. Furnishings are very European Victorian in style. Signage, one small sign right at the entrance, is hard to see before you pass the site. Worthy of a visit to get a closer...


More  



Had a great docent., Wonderful history of the family and Hawaiin history. Sad what we did to their culture. Beautiful furnishings. My husband and I both love old houses and this was a treat.

This is a lovely old home that gives you a little bit more history of Queen Emma. You can walk into each room and see beautiful carved furniture and old settees. Beautifully maintained, not a large exhibit, but well done. Barbara the woman taking admission was very informative.

Queen Emma Summer Palace is a gem just outside of Honolulu city. Beautifully maintained by the Daughters of Hawaii, this palace captures the spirit of Hawaiian royalty during the period of the monarchy. Be sure to notice the standards made of feathers and the adorable cribs for royal babies.

We took a bus to see this. We had a great tour and explanation of everything. We were there a few years ago and not on this trip, but if you like history, it is a great place to visit

Queen Emma did much for Hawaii. She had this palace (actually a DIY home from Massachusetts) built high above Honolulu in a beautiful location. Many artifacts from as far away as England as Emma and Victoria were friends. Emma started Queen's Hospital and is important history of the islands. Travis gave us an stupendous tour.

I lived in Kailua for 5 years, and now we have a vacation rental condo in Waikiki, so I have driven past the Queen Emma Summer Palace on the Pali Hwy probably hundreds, if not thousands, of times. However, I had never visited this historic place. Finally, one rainy day, we decided to stop by and check it out.

We were there for the Smithsonian Museum weekend. We thought the house and grounds were well maintained, with some interesting information and artifacts concerning Queen Emma. I liked this better than the palace.

title: Spitting Cave of Portlock, Honolulu
review_list:
A must see at the over look point. Worth the stop and the view. Also a great scenic stop on your way to the North Shore.

This is an unknown little jewel of Oahu. Its a short walk down to the viewing area. Very nice only takes a few minutes.

Beautiful beach and amazing landscape! The water is so very blue! We enjoyed a beautiful afternoon here. Bring a picnic lunch!

Definitely worth checking out. I found it the area fairly easy using google maps. Once I got there, I used the directions from the other reviews and found it without a problem. There is a climb down but it's not very hard. Just use good shoes to avoid slipping. It was peaceful and quiet. There were only three other people...

This was a little hard to find. I had to call my host to ask her where to find it. There is currently ( Jan 2016) a house under construction. If you go past and circle the dead end you will see a very small chain link fence that allows you access to the Spitting Caves. Make sure you have...

The entrance is in a quiet residential neighborhood. We went on a Saturday morning to start our self-guided island tour. Spectacular views and we enjoyed the quick stop. We had young kids and we had to restrict them to areas away from the edges.

This site is very beautiful and in a very exclusive part of Oahu. Beautiful beach mixed with expensive multimillion dollar homes truly looks like paradise. The spitting cave is awesome, beautiful, but also dangerous. Just be cautious and use your judgment to ensure your safety as well as others. Follow appropriate precautions as enjoy the cave.

This place is gorgeous! Dangerous but freakin gorgeous! We went here with friends and they took some engagement pictures for us. You would never find it unless you were actually looking for it but defiantly worth it. You feel like your on the edge of the world! Enjoy and be careful!

One of my favorite spots to visit on the island. This unknown gem on the eastern corner near Hanauma Bay is well worth the stop. Just a quick 50 yard hike down a dirt path between a house under construction brings you to a spectacular view!
Great place for a sunset, sunbathing or a light picnic. During the winter months...

Easy to get to. Worth pulling over to get some pictures. Another wonder to see in Hawaii. Not far from great snorkling.

title: Food Pantry, Honolulu
review_list:
Very convenient supermarket location, close to major hotels. Decent selection of food items and ok prices.

Food pantry is situated close to the Ohana west hotel,so is convenient for those late night munchies and/or a glass of beer and bubbly.

A good option to purchasing food and fruit to have instead of having take away fast food. Central to Waikikki beach.

After looking at the store of the Hilton Grand Waikikian Resort and paying way to much for a dinner there, we realized we needed a cheaper option, A short walk from the resort to the Food Pantry was the answer! If the person we rented the condo from did not tell us I am sure we would have struggled to buy what we needed. The food pantry is at 2370 Kuhio and was about 10 minute walk from our condo in Ohua Ave and it has all you would need if you are catering for yourself. Fresh meat, bread, salad,...

This is a great place to stock up on everything. The Aussie dollar is not good and so eating out for all meals is expensive. This place you can get everything you can think of.

The food pantry is the way to avoid the high price of restaurants in Waikiki. They have everything including hot food for take out (the rotisserie chicken is marvelous as is the fried rice. We got chicken, rice, and desserts for 2 for just over $13. It is convenient to the Hilton Hawaiian Village, about a five minute walk.

Our condo was down the street from the Food Pantry so it was very convenient for us. The service was good with friendly and helpful employees. Enjoyed walking around downtown, both in the afternoon and evening. Lots of shops, restaurants and places to take a break when walking around. Good view of the harbour as well. Never felt unsafe at night, but there were a lot of homeless people/druggies walking around at night.

there is always a lot of people downtown, and when the sun goes down the street walkers come out, ladies of the street and drug heads. title: Izumo Taishakyo Mission of Hawaii, Honolulu
review_list:
I met the head priest of the temple, and he was one of the most pure, simple, lovely human beings I have ever met. His name was Daiya. It's worth it to get a feel for the Japanese history of Hawaii.

Saw this temple while on a guided city tour. Returned to investigate this majestic structure located on the edge of Chinatown. I discovered that it is a one of a few Shinto shrines in the US. Although I am not Shintoist, I used the opportunity to purchase omamori (amulets) for good health. After reading information posted at the front gate...


More  



Usually ample parking make this small, but well maintained shrine a nice stop while in downtown. The staff are quite friendly and they have a nice selection of omomori. We've taken pictures in front of it and friends had all wondered where in Japan we were.

Very popular with Asian tourists, this impressive and serene Shrine was built in 1922 by master Japanese builders, but has been around for 110 years. For some, there is little to see here but the alter, some chairs, and a gift shop. If you'd like to pray (Shintoism IS the spontaneous and natural worship of spiritual forces), there are helpful...


More  



Visit the temple in downtown Chinatown Honolulu on the first day of the new year to get blessed and buy amulets for prosperity, good health, driving safety and fertility. The Shinto shrine is open year round but especially festive on New Year day.

My family makes a visit on or around New Year's to this shrine for blessings for the
coming year. There is a ritual to follow and there is instruction posted at the entrance. For the first few days of the New Year, a priest is there for a ceremony. It is customary to give a donation in the box located...


More  



This is a classic Shingon temple, based on the Idzumo model, found on the Sea of Japan side of Honshu. One walks under a torii, uses the water function to the right and then walks up the steps. Usually the door is open and one can look inside and pray. Upon leaving, one rings the bells and exits. It's a...


More  



This is one of a very few Shinto Shrines on U.S. soil. It is small, but architecturally and culturally interesting. This Shinto sect has been in Hawaii for over one hundred years, but during WWII the shrine was confiscated and closed by the city. It re-opened in 1968
When you enter the shrine you should cleanse your hands at the...


More  



This temple stands out on the street, and quickly draws your attention as one of the most ornate buildings in or near Chinatown. I was a little intimidated to go to this mission because none of the reviews were in English, but I am so glad I went. It was very beautiful, and very spiritually moving. title: Honolulu Harbor, Honolulu
review_list:
I like boats, ships, the ocean - but there is nothing here. You may be lucky and have a few unique boats in, be careful of the barges people make into looking something other than it is (pirate boat)

Watched the cruise ships come and go. Visited the Aloha Tower, where you can do some shopping and grab a bite to eat. Clean, lots of places to take a seat to relax. Not much more to do other than that or venturing into downtown.

I went to Honolulu Harbor to go on the whale-watching cruise. The harbor was pretty & clean. The cruise was fantastic! We saw some whales, although they were pretty far away. The ship was very nice. They have a nice restaurant.

I've been to Oahu twice and it is always exiting, while being moving to my soul. This Island enriches my soul in every way. In memory of sacrifice and bravery, I will never tire of the sights and lessons of Pearl Harbor.

One of many harbors around Honolulu, this harbor is mostly industrial with Aloha Tower being its centerpiece. There are a few restaurants there plus lots of Hawai'i Pacific University students, as well as the two cruise lines that ply the waters three times a day, giving tours and insight.

Some changes there, but lots of boats and ships to see. Aloha Tower shops now dorms and classrooms but tower still there to go up and enjoy the view.

I have been to the Waterfront there isn't much to see or do unless u go about down to where are the boat tours are. I know this is comparing apples to oranges but I've been to Seattle's Waterfront now that was something spectacular ours is boring.

This is a nice place to walk or sit for a while. My husband and I even ran through here a couple of days during our stay in Honolulu. Get a feel for a modern day fishing village!

Magnificent place to drive or walk around. Great place to stop and eat or to pick up one of the many tours, cruises or dinner cruises. Top location.

Honolulu Harbor is a nice area to walk around and relax while taking a look at all the boats and ships in the area. It's nice to watch all the incoming and outgoing traffic. We found several places to eat and drink around the area although we didn't try any of them. A good way to kill a little time.

title: Saint Andrew's Cathedral, Honolulu
address: Queen Emma Square, Honolulu, Oahu, HI 96813-2304

British looking church. Kamehameha IV wanted his own church, it got built in 1861, 4 years after his death on St. Andrews day. Very beautiful Gothic-style church in Honolulu and worth a quick visit. However, I wouldn't go out of my way to see it. Instead, pair it with another Honolulu attraction, such as the Iolani Palace or the National Cemetery.

We were fortunate to be in Honolulu on a Wednesday because that is when the Cathedral has its noontime concerts (also on Fridays). I had discovered this fact online before traveling to Honolulu. A beautiful setting, beautiful music, a beautiful day.

title: Honolulu Hale (City Hall), Honolulu

An annual tradition of families in Hawaii is to tour the decorated trees and wreaths at City Hall aka Honolulu Hale. From the majestic tree on the front lawn to handcrafted wreaths on the inside there's something for all ages to enjoy.

This is a lovely building in the middle of downtown Honolulu. Worth walking by, even if you don't have time to go in. The architecture is a little different from the rest of the architecture in the rest of the city.

Each year the Christmas tree lighting is a gala event with a spectacular parade, carnival-like food booths, and entertainment. The ceremony itself is fashioned in a manner that each mayor, since Mayor Frank Fasi first established this event, personalizes. Just one night, once a year. It is delightful.

A nice building that uses a large lobby to often house exhibits and community issues, Honolulu's City Hall is a beautiful building. It is well lit at night and is the center of holiday lights in December. There is nothing more to see as you pass (really) on your way to the State Capitol, the Mission Homes or Iolani Palace.

Honolulu Hale is the political seat of the City and County of Honolulu. "Hale" meaning "home" also implies a meeting place. The mayor and City Council have offices here and public meeting rooms are open. Don't forget to go to the basement. The photos of all of Honolulu's mayors line the wall. title: Ali'iolani Hale, Honolulu
review_list:
To be honest the only reason we stopped is because the family are big Hawaii 5-0 fans so how could we not get a picture in front of it!
Parking is very limited but we did find a spot in the lot to the left of the building.

Visiting the royal palace provided some insight into the opulent lifestyle of the last Hawaiian dynasty. Unfortunately I suspect that the docent gave a somewhat slanted view of the royal family painting them more as victims of white imperialism while playing down their obvious excesses at the probable expense of the islanders.

5-O headquarters only on TV!
Ali'iōlani Hale was started in 1872 and completed two years later. Designed by Thomas Rowe, the building was originally going to be a palace and serve as the King's residence. But, this was changed and the building housed the Kingdom treasury, Supreme Court, and other government offices. Today, it continues to be the Hawai'i State...


More  



We were able to visit on Christmas Day. No traffic, parking up front, perfect! Although the facility was closed, we were able to walk around the building and check the landscape out. The old growth trees are amazing! So glad we made the stop!

Of course everyone recognizes this from Hawaii Five-o television show. The building itself is interesting with some unusual architecture.

Perhaps one of the most recognizable features of Oahu due to both the original series and the current as it is used in the opening credits. The building is architecturally beautiful. Across the street from Iolani Palace.

My boyfriend & I watch Hawaii 5-0 so we thought we should stop by here. It was very quick maybe a 10 minute stop. We parked on the side of the road using meter parking. It was cool to see just because we watch the show, other than that nothing too too special. We didn't actually go in the building...


More  



The history of Hawaiian law is explained here. The Supreme Court is actually in this building and it is still in operation. How they incorporate a museum and a court in the same building. Very informative.

We visited Ali'iolani Hale as part of our city tour. Interesting building with a chance for several photo ops. A must for 5-0 fans.

We didn't have much time to spend here but it is well worth taking a few minutes to see a key part of the history of Hawaii!

IL

title: Koko Crater Botanical Garden, Honolulu

title: Sans Souci Beach Park, Honolulu
review_list:
All of the commercial activity at Waikiki has its charm, but if you're going to enjoy the beach, this is the place. At the far end of the strand it is easily accessible and Uncrowded. You might even catch some locals playing Ukelele and singing.

If you want to escape the hordes at Waikiki Beach, consider coming here.
Just down the road a short 5-10 minutes, right near the New Otani Hotel. Parking can be a challenge...but where isn't it, in Honolulu :) Many fish in the clear water.
Clean sand, a bit more relaxing with terrific views of beautiful Waikiki.

This is a beautiful, peaceful beach at the end of Waikiki. It's far enough away that you don't get the crowds, but you get the same beautiful views!

On most days, the water by the beach is great for toddlers. There are not many beaches as suited for them.

Great place; mostly tourist-free! So close to the hell of Waikiki but far enough away to keep most of the tourists away. I hate Waikiki due to the throngs of people. review_list:

The Mission House was a housing kit brought to Honolulu by New England missionaries. A basement came as part of the housing kit. Basements aren't very convenient in Hawaii. The basement was really hot and stuffy.

title: Foodland Ala Moana, Honolulu
address: 1450 Ala Moana Blvd., Honolulu, Oahu, HI 96814
review_list:
Would have shopped if if had been their and opened but it's gone and the closest one is a good 20 minutes away, so guess what Don Quiote got our money and will continue to get our business

My fave grocery store at Ala Moana is gone gone gone. Options are nearby Don Quijote and Food Pantry on Kuhio. I miss Foodland's deli. Apparently a new one will open in the mall addition. In the meantime, don't bank on FL at AM for your tourist grub.

This grocery store is located in central Honolulu, one street of the main road. You can compare prices to Don Quijote and the Ala Moana grocery store and come out equal. It has a deli and fresh seafood daily. Also, importantly to me, you can buy newspapers from many Canadian and US sources. Their poke is delicious.

Since it seems like poke is (was) a star attraction at this full service grocery store, be sure to visit the other Foodland locations such as Market City and Beretania to buy poke!

Had to go here for the Ahi poke! Wow! Was it great. To have such a deli back home! The entire store was great. We picked up a half loaf of French bread and a bottle of wine and made a picnic with our ahi poke, muscles and kimchi crab.

There are plenty of options for places to eat at this food court. The biggest in Oahu as far as I know. There are several local eats here as well as a few places for dessert!

Love this store and the employees in it. Sadly it is closing. The Ala Moana Mall is renovating and raising rents. The Foodland Company announced that they couldn't justify staying. So sad, the store convenient, with a great poke counter. Great while it lasted.

We ALWAYS go to this store for poke, desserts and their deli. if you're staying in Ala Moana, they have everything you need for your stay. Fast and friendly service!!

Great variety of deli style foods and snacks. We bought half a lb of shoyu marinated ahi poke and ate it raw... Extremely delicious! You can't get ahi this quality back home in oz from any style market! Buy all you products and at the checkout mention you wish to become a maikai member, just give them your contact number...

We had a great evening exploring Waikiki and its surrounding areas.The Ala Wai canal was a sweet surprise.Beautiful and serene.

i got what i was looking for! peace and quiet areas and when its party time, lots of them. shopping is super great! from knickknacks to MK's, and ross, fruits to spinach. everything was done right! you'll find everything under the sun in Hawaii!

If you're staying in Waikiki, there are several great running routes. Ala Wai is one of them, with a wide sidewalk and lovely views. If you find Kalakaua Ave really crowded (even at 6:30 am!), then check out Ala Wai.

We passed the Ala Wai canal several times coming and going to Waikiki. Seemed to be used mostly by rowers practising for events.

Not sure it's a visit more like you drive by it. On the trolley the driver went into some stuff about it. It was pretty cool to see how much after it rained the canal rose. Not something I would go out of my way to visit, nor did I get off the trolley to check it out.

title: Arnold's Tiki Bar, Honolulu
review_list:
Everyone knows that it costs a fortune to get a decent Mai Tai in Waikiki, all the bars are sterile fake tourist traps. Well you don't know Arnold.....
This is a great dive tiki bar where you can get great cocktails at decent prices, forget paying $14 on the beach when you can basically get three for the same price...


More  



The wife and I were in Oahu and looking for some local bars and unique places. This is definitely one of those. We stopped by before they opened and ended up at their sister bar only to find out that they opened a little later. It's not beach side and quite a challenge to find which makes it unique to...


More  



it is a local bar with local music not much for seating but great vibe and drinks were cheap for Oahu

its worth all the walk from Waikiki beach... best mai tais in a relaxing environment!! definitely recommend!!

This bar was so close to our hotel Luana Waikiki, it was perfect for a couple of drinks on our way out each evening. It's a small place, with character, good drinks selection and live music at the weekends. Great atmosphere and worth a visit.

Great little outdoor bar with cheap drinks and open courtyard. Was here on a weeknight and it has a younger vibe. Recommend for people who just want to chill out after a long day. Great service.

We ate here twice with friends and family. Great atmosphere, good food and great wait staff. Not too pricey and lots of fun. Would definitely recommend.

Great atmosphere, and just like the sort of tropical bar in Hawaii I'd imagined it would be. The staff were friendly, the bar food yummy, and the drinks were cold.

Pretty divey locals bar near Waikiki. Decently cheap drinks, but not super well-made cocktails. Nice outdoor area though!

This is definitely a local bar for a younger crowd. They've got the cheapest drinks we found on our trip and it was a fun place but it sort of feels like you're walking into a Hawaiian house party.

title: Honolulu Museum of Art Spalding House, Honolulu
address: 2411 Makiki Heights Drive, Honolulu, Oahu, HI 96822 (Formerly The Contemporary Museum)
review_list:
We went there twice already. The loxation of museum is great, garden and pool simply beautiful. Some exhibitions better than the others. We love the place si much that we choose to take few wedding shots there. I would recomend anyone to go there. For me is one of not many places in Honolulu you have to see.

The Spalding House is included in the fee to visit the Honolulu Museum of Art. We drove up after visiting the museum, only to find that the exhibits inside the house were closed for renovation. We strolled the grounds, which are peaceful and beautiful. You can walk a path down into a lush ravine. There is a separate building with...


More  



Granted I'm not what you'd call a big art aficionado, but I do especially enjoy contemporary art...we visited on the 1st Weds of the month when it's free (hubby doesn't enjoy art museums at all & stayed in the garden to read a book).
The gardens are truly lovely & afford nice views of HNL...few people around meant quiet peaceful...


More  



The museum overlooks Honolulu and its beautiful gardens are almost worth the admission price in themselves. The current special exhibit, TXT/MSG, is a provocative, interactive exploration of what communication amounts to. A separate building houses David Hockney's re-imagining of his stage design for the opera "L'enfant et les Sortileges." It's like entering a painting.

We were definately impressed by the real estate. The grounds are attractive, and the staff is very friendly here. Some interactive exhibits as well. Went through everything in about an hour.

The Spalding House location of the Honolulu Museum of Art is a beautiful house, built in the hills overlooking Honolulu. Even if you don't go into the museum (which was unfortunately closed the day we were there) the grounds and the view are magnificent! It's definitely worth the short but steep drive up from the city. A view that is...


More  



You can get into the Spalding House for free on the same day as you go to the Honolulu Museum of Art, so I would advise doing that. There is a small parking lot by the building where you can park during your visit. The galleries are nice, but the real beauty lies in the grounds, which are stunning.

Went with friends. We went through the museum which is contemporary art-currently a focus on origami. It's not a large museum but is interesting. The smaller building has the Daniel Hockney exhibit which is like going into an Alice in Wonderland kind of experience. He did a set for an opera which is reflected in the exhibit. There is a...


More  



We had lunch and wandered the grounds. The food was Greek inspired and YUMMY!!!! You can eat indoors, outside in front of the museum gift shop under a canopy. Or you can have a picnic on the grounds. We will go back again to see the art indoors another time.

Wonderful grounds. Great spot to getaway from midday heat & crowds down below. My favorite spot in Honolulu on a nice day. Don't miss it.

title: Kakaako Waterfront Park, Honolulu
address: 677 Ala Moana Boulevard, Suite 1001, Honolulu, Oahu, HI 96813
review_list:
This is an amazing beach! It's beautiful, has incredible views, and it's not as crowded as some other beaches, at least not while we were there.

This beach used to be a bare field, with a small path leading to the black rocks where we would jump in with our fins and bodyboards and Rush 'Point Panic'! A destination place for all Honolulu residents; but especially for the Kaka'ako Maua residents...... When President Barack Obama live in Honolulu he use to surf here.....

I was waiting for my friend and as a tourist after 4pm (which is the time most attractions close), I instinctively looked for the sea. The closest park was the Kakaako Waterfront Park. What a beautiful place to catch the Hawaiian sunset.
We typically have family picnics here as its fairly clean and the parking is ample and close to the picnic tables. Even on the weekends we notice that the park employees are cleaning up the area. Yes at times the grass could be better keep but oh well.

Came here for the NYE party and it was fantastic. Drinks are expensive so id recommend pre-gaming. There were different stages and DJ's playing EDM music and the fireworks were killer.

Growing up in sweet Hawai'i nei, Kakaako was one of my favorite places to visit. To just sit out on the rock wall, plate lunch in hand staring out into the ocean. I've visited there many times with my daughter when she rode her bike, and with friends to cast a lei for her father whose ashes were scattered there. We've had picnics there. First I have to say I am a little biased. My husband and I got married here at Kakaako, standing on the rocks with the water splashing below us. So, needless to say it was beautiful. title: Old Waialua Sugar Mill, Honolulu
review_list:
Great place to stop , stretch, and look around. Very friendly staff and management. Lots and lots of stuff to look at and buy ! A little tour of the coffee & cacao beans is always good . Don't forget the surf shop and the soap shop next door too .

Pretty cute place here. Not too much to look at but very friendly people who are will give you a tour around the sugar mill

Love this place, excellent coffee! They will explain to you the process of how coffee is made and harvested and allow you to ry a sample. They do close around 5 pm so plan your trip accordingly. Great place to find souvenirs and a lot of local goods, like spices, candles jams etc...

I went on a Saturday and the Farmer's Market was open. They had fruits and vegetables, rotisserie chicken (I was told to have a fried banana, but they were not there that weekend. The coffe company had excellent local coffee, chocolate, and other gifts at reasonable prices. There are a number of stores. This is a good stop!

Such a neat place! With an eye to preserving the history of the mill this plantation offers a small tour of their coffee and chocolate process. Make sure you get a sample of their coffee and chocolates! Lots of touristy purchase options and a large variety of coffee beans to buy including 100% kona coffee beans.

Listen, if you want the best shaved ice on the island come here! It's not artificial, chemical favors poured over chunks of ice like you find I. So many other places. This is powder, freshly shaved in front of you ice. There are flavors ranging from mango, coconut, avocado, lilikoi, watermelon, strawberry, and even chocolate. We got a generous small...


More  



Off the beaten path with different wares for sale, we enjoyed looking through the old mill at what was on offer. Unfortunately it was pouring rain so we didn't get a chance for the tour of the coffee and chocolate manufacturing process but staff answered all kinds of questions and were eager to share knowledge. We stopped here on our latest visit to Oahu. It was interesting to take the small tour on how the coffee and chocolate were processed, as well as sample both. We've been twice and really enjoyed both times.

Lots of tourist things to purchase for gifts etc!
Staff are friendly and willing for you to try all the samples!
We will be back!

This is a really nice shopping center that most people miss because they are headed to Ala Moana but I would suggest some time there. They have alot of different stores there. It has been years since we shopped here , it is way better than the other outlets store in the island . The map is difficult to follow and I would suggest you get your barrings in the day light as we got totally lost .

if you have time to spare then I would suggest that you take a drive around the rain forest and stop at the different look out points. The views are amazing.

Part of our drive around Oahu. A great place to stop and gaze at the views. Can be windy and while there appeared to be a park person in a vehicle when you exited, no one was paying the self service parking fee and he was not stopping anyone for the fee.

The views are mesmerizing. It is very windy so be to sure to dress warmly. Great place to have pictures taken.

title: Kuan Yin Temple, Honolulu

title: Royal Mausoleum State Monument (Mauna Ala), Honolulu
review_list:
Worth a stop if you are interested in Hawaiian history. The grounds are well kept and there are numerous other places to visit in the same general area.

This was one of our stops on our tour of Iolani Palace, and Queen Emma's Summer Palace. Beautiful grounds and lots of history.

Reverent, peaceful last resting place of most of the Hawaiian monarch and their descendants. The ONLY piece of land that remains in Hawaiian kingdom/crown lands. It is sovergin Hawaiian Land. Visit the final resting places of the Kamehameha and Kalakaua lines.

Walking down here from the Queen Emma’s Summer House is well worth it. It only takes about 20 minutes to visit.

It is important to know that if you are visiting Mauna Ala that it is a very special place to Hawaiian people and culture. It is the place where Hawaiian royalty is buried. That being said, proper attire and decorum should be exhibited while there. There are times when very few people are on the grounds. At other times, ceremony...


More  



In all my trips to Hawaii I actually never realized this existed to be able to see it as a visitor. I was shocked and surprised to be able to go see it and pay my respects to the Royals of the Hawaiian Islands. The Grounds were peaceful and Spiritual in nature not at all like a tourist attraction. We...


More  



I've come here a couple of times before: to see the grounds, the tombs, the crypt, the chapel. But, what about the inside of the chapel? This time, a friend somehow talked the groundskeeper(?) into letting us peek inside. Wow. The austere-looking exterior gives no hint what's inside: warm koa wood paneling, wood beams and vaulted ceiling. Simply beautiful. I...


More  



If you visit The Bishop Museum and The Palace where Hawaii's last Queen lived before the Royal Family were thrown out of power, then make sure you check The Royal Mausoleum where the Queen and other members of the Royal Family were laid to rest. Not much to see, but the history is amazing.

Wahi makamae, which means precious place in the Hawaiian language, is a great way of describing Mauna ʻAla. This is the burial place of the royalty of Hawaiʻi. It is worth every minute of your time to visit and experience the spirit of the place and learn about our royals of old of whom I descend. Yes, I am a...


More  



But they do a beautiful job at keep up the grounds. Many of the last bits of royalty in Hawaii are buried there. Check out the underground mausoleum and chapel. Read the story behind both.

title: Mu Ryang Sa Buddhist Temple, Honolulu

Calming and natural site with beautiful temple buildings. Excellent retreat from the noise of Oahu. Visit the Pali lookout on the way there.

All of the above... this Buddhist Temple was recommended by a friend who had visited a few weeks prior to our arrival in Honolulu. Nice and peaceful place. Beautiful to take pictures. The only thing I didn't like is that you have to actually enter a cemetery to get there. Te temple is located inside a very nice and beautiful cemetery. Just so you know. ;)

Hawaii doesn't feel like it's in the USA, and places like this amplify that feeling. It feels like one is in Asia. Splendid atmosphere, Wonderful views of Honolulu, Inspiring color combinations!

What a lovely place to visit to get away from the bustle of Waikiki. We visited as part of a circle tour of the island. Definitely worth the visit. The fish are huge!! The temple itself is quite small but the grounds alone are worth stopping by. Be sure to look in the gift shop at the chimes of varying...


More  



Beautiful and quiet. This was so relaxing and a nice break from the tourist scene even though we were on a tour at the time. My daughter loved to ring the bell and she went wild taking lots of photos.

A refreshing change from the plastic of Waikiki. This is an real Buddhist temple being used by the local community. It is very beautiful and tranquil - well worth a visit if you have a car.

They are all over base just like on the rest of the island. We did not go to the museum, so I can not make any recommendations about that.

In my husbands family 2 fascinating and unforgivable experiences happened. His first cousin Hilary Gazarian was born here in Oahu on the infamous day of Dec 7, 1941. His Uncle Bill Lawlor was already a 21 year old in the navy and top deckside of the USS Arizona in Pearl harbor close by, he lived yet the blast catapulted him...

went there on way to pearl harbour very intresting place as "From Here to Eternity" was filmed at here. Worth a vist as the Museum contains displays of weaponry the display of artillery and armor is nice.

We were invited to eat in a NCO Club...very good food. We took the tour, and the story of Schofield Barracks is under told, and we were very interested in the photos and the lay out. A US Army Sgt. was our guide, and he was exceptional.

I spent a week with my son, daughter-in-law, and two grandsons. I had a blast!! If you are ever able to visit the base get some guava chicken and shrimp in front of the PX.

We enjoyed very much visiting the Schofield Barracks installation and the history museum. It's a must for anyone interested in the history of the US Army relative to the 25th Infantry Division in particular.

The history you are able to see and experience is awesome. Best to go Monday through Thursday so you can see the museum also. Be prepared to stop and have your car inspected as well as answering questions before you can access the Barracks.

title: Judiciary Building, Honolulu
review_list:

I went during an open house and we just basically walked around and read the stuff on the walls. Wasn't much to it. Thankfully it was free.

We went to visit the King Kamehameha Statue and ended up going inside. The man and woman working the museum inside were so informative. You could tell they loved their job. We learned a lot about the history of the courts in Hawaii, especially martial law during WWII. The building is as great inside as it is outside!

This monarchy-era building, Once the "House of Nobles" branch of the Kingdom and now thehome of the State Supreme Court, andother offices has been sensitively restored to its' original intent and splendour. One wonders how a government agency managed to do this without gumming it up?

If you watch Hawaii Five-0 then you would defiantly know this building! The famous King Kamehameha statue is in front of this great architectural building! So much history surrounds this place. We did a tour of the island and I am so glad we got to go here and see this sight in person! Beware.. there are a great number...


More  



We very much enjoyed a day here not far from the Capitol building
lots of good information and helpful staff. Would really like to visit again

The building is beautiful, wonderfully restored a few years ago, especially the entry rotunda. To the left is a fabulous small museum detailing the history of Hawaiian justice, from pre-contact through to the evolution of Western ideas of justice and law, beautifully designed and executed.

We stopped by to see the statue and of course to see the fictional headquarters of Hawaii-50. I had to get my picture taken in front of "50 headquarters". As the tv show grows in popularity, I am sure more people will go and get their picture taken in front of it too.

I did this hike with 2 girlfriends last fall and the entire time I kept thinking how beautiful it was, how I couldn't wait to show my mom when she finally got the chance to come to Hawaii for her first time. Definitely some of the most breath taking views in all the island. I've done almost every public hike...


More  



The new iron fence at the entrance of the trail and the warning sign are very clear signal from the land owner that the land is private property, not public land. Let's respect other people's property like we want others to respect ours. I certainly don't want other people to trespass into my property. Hawaii is a beautiful island and...


More  



Mariner's Ridge, owned by a private estate, has been officially closed since April 2013 with a couple of sings but many hikers ignored the warning and entered the trail crossing the chains. As another reviewer reported, a senior tourist fell off and died from a combination of heart attack and the fall in June. A couple of weeks later, a...


More  



We hiked this trail and found it tough but doable for most Bring water and good shoes a walking stick would be helpful The sites are great and will reward your efforts Didn't like the chains saying keep out These trails are for all and I hope they will stay free for the public. I found the trail clean and...


More  



The trail can be a little challenging in places for a weekend warrior, but the views were incredible!

The Mariner's Ridge trail is now closed. Toward the end of June, a Korean man, 70 years old, fell to his death at the lookout. So sad.
In February, I fell and broke my wrist as I started to descend from the lookout. (I walked out).
Violators may be persecuted. Try hiking the Makiki Hights trail instead.

One of the most popular trails in Honolulu, Mariner's Ridge trail is at the top of a hill in residential community in east Honolulu. Owned by a large private estate, the trail is now closed to the public with two warnings not to trespass. There's obviously a liability issue in case hikers get injured. In recent years, the number of...


More  



I drove an hour and a half from north shore to this trail only to find that it is closed as of April 5th 2013! There are chains and signs posted that prohibit entry. I did not want to risk being "prosecuted" as the signs stated or having my car impounded. Find another trail-

This hike is not for everyone.I'm 60 in great shape and had no problem.But I would say some people would have a tough time with this hike.The views are amazing when you get to the top.

Very nice trail that starts in a neighborhood community. The hike up took longer than I thought it would take, and there were several spots closer to the end of the trail where it was difficult to hike, but the view at the top is incredible! wear some good hiking shoes, b/c there were some parts that were slippery due...

title: China Walls, Honolulu
review_list:
A lava shelf extending a good portion of the way around the base of Koko Head towards Hanauma Bay, offers a pretty easy walk along the water's edge, with access from a vacant lot near the end of Hanapepe Loop. One thing to watch for is the wet area along the cliff, otherwise known as the splash area, which can...


More  



One of those off the beaten path places to visit. Its easy to find using Google maps. It's at the end of a residential street in the Koko Kai Beach Park, so make sure you watch where you park. There was a cop sitting on the street issuing parking tickets to those people who were in the no parking zone....


More  



Lots of people were cliff jumping here, but I did not. This is a pretty place for a picnic, although it was quite crowded on the weekday we were there.

This place is off the beaten path and in a neighborhood area. Parking is down the street and do not park in the cul-de-sac or you will be ticketed. It's a great spot for swimming and sun bathing but beware the waves on larger days because the waves will sweep over the rocks and drag you into the ocean and...


More  



We parked in a beautiful neighborhood that has easy access to China Walls. Be careful because if the waves are big the rock cliffs get a little slippery. We evens saw 4 whales while just walking along the walls. My boyfriends brother jumped off the walls right above the spitting caves, but the caves weren't "spitting" the day we went....
