address: Old Pali Highway, Honolulu, Oahu, HI 96817
review_list:
To get to the ruins you need to hike through the bamboo forest. It is normally very muddy. Bring extra shoes towels and some water to rinse off after the hike.

Took a 4, 6, and 9 year old and they were fine. Great Hawaii history!
Very private peaceful walk in a bamboo forest. Muddy but there are ways around most of it.

Decided to do this quick hike after doing Lulumahu falls. Easy hike and I was the only one on the trail - was able to see this beautiful site on my own. Peaceful. If you are looking for a hike for the sake of hiking - this may not be your trail. If you are looking for a pretty easy...


More  



I've been meaning to come here for a while. Finally, drove out on the Pali. Turned on Old Pali Road and just past the water station (if you're heading towards Kailua), you'll find a trail into a bamboo forest on the left side of the road. Take the trail and hop over one log before making another left. About 100...


More  



1847 era ruins of Hawaiian King Kaniakapupu. Still standing are 4 walls, the long stone main entrance and the huge luau pit.
Getting there is half the fun. It starts from the same main entrance as for the Lulumahu Falls hike. The website directions are not at all clear and finding this place is very challenging. Enter through the designated...

title: Kealia Trail, Honolulu
address: Near Dillingham Airfield, Mokuleia, Honolulu, Oahu, HI 96791
review_list:
"Great Short Hike with an Awesome View form the top"
We have hiked this several times, and there are several other trails that you can do once you reach the top. There is one trail called "Are Loop" in memory of a lost hiker who was never found. You can also hike the Forest reserve. Some of the other hikes...

Great views of the North Shore, and a good easy, but sweaty hike up the mountain. about 19 switchbacks.

Definitely worth an hour or two to ride the whole path back and forth and linger a bit along the way. There are beautifully placed picnic tables towards the North end of the path (past Kealia beach), so next time we'll time our ride late in the afternoon and bring a few things to eat. We rented our bicycles from...


More  



Very good trail! Be ready to get a workout, your legs will feel it! The trail ends in a picnic area; however, you can continue walking but not sure where it ends. We walked 15 more minutes and still no end! Free parking dillingham airfield

This is a very good hiking trail. The first 1.3 miles is all uphill on switchbacks up a 1000' cliff. At the top, you will find a picnic table with a great view of Dillingham Airfield and the North Shore. From here you can continue on a 4 wheel drive road through the mountains. title: Nohea Gallery, Honolulu
address: 1050 Ala Moana Blvd., Ward Warehouse, Honolulu, Oahu, HI 96815
review_list:
The Nohea Gallery is home to a large selection of unique art from many different local artisans. In general, there are pictures, general home décor and knick-knacks, and jewelry, along with a few toys. Most things are on the pricy side, but they really are unique. The staff is warm and friendly; also, they are willing to work with the...


More  



Nohea Gallery was one of our first stops in Honolulu. We loved wooden turned bowls and the Nohea Gallery has a fine collection. Also a good collection of jewelry, other wood work, ceramics, paintings. It's tucked away in the Ward Center (which also houses the Na'Mea Bookstore, another source for Ni'ihau shell jewelry and turned bowls).

It was a trip to the Ward Warehouse (really a collection of shops in a two-storey complex), but it was worth it. Nohea Gallery has a large and varied selection of beautiful things from earrings to a custom-painted surfboard. I bought gorgeous made in Hawaii glass beads for my Pandora bracelet at a more affordable price. The earrings my daughter...


More  



I return to this gallery every trip to Hawaii. The selection of art by Hawaiian artists is impressive. The great thing is that there is something for most budgets, from a freshwater pearl necklace for $25 to original oil paintings in the hundreds. The mediums include carved wood, jewelry, paintings, sculpture...something for anyone looking to take some Hawaiian art home.

Slightly off the beaten track, in the Ward Warehouse, this gallery/shop used to have a satellite in a Waikiki hotel, but that shop closed, and now this is the only way to see their amazing collection of goods. It's all by local artisans, and includes a very wide range; paintings and ceramics and jewelry are eye-opening, but what we liked...

I saw this shop as I was walking down Kalakaua Avenue and it was a good excuse to enter the venerable Moana Hotel, which is awsome in it's own right. This shop is really nice! It has things that are wonderful souveniers of Hawaii without being touristy. Their stock is made by artists in Hawaii, not China or the Philipines....


More  



Friends at home suggested I visit a few art and gift galleries in Honolulu while there on business. I tried Chinatown, a back street spot I never did find, Waikiki, Ala Moana Shopping Center and the Ward Street area. Break out your long distance walking shoes! I just wanted to see how good the local art scene is and I...


More  



The Nohea Gallery offers well made and locally produced gifts and souveniers for visitors to Hawaii. It's location inside the Moana Surfrider is convenient, but be prepared to pay the price for that convenience. The same locally produced gifts can be purchased at many other locations throughout the island of Oahu at significantly lower prices.

title: Lucoral Museum, Honolulu
review_list:
Really disappointed. Made all the way here only to found out that it's already closed on a Monday afternoon 2.30pm ? Though the light was on, metal shutters was down with a car in it. Many attempts to call them to no avail.

A small (free of fee) museum almost hidden from sight but when you come in, you would find a new world: all sorts of corals and pearls not only from Hawaii but from around the globe. A visit there enriches the visitor who would be astound in front of the richness, especially of corals. Im memoriam of Mrs. Lu.

We walked past here quite a few times and didn't know what it was. I looked it up on trip advisor and saw that it was a museum of gemstones. I decided to take my daughter here and its her favorite part of our trip. The staff was great and super knowledgeable. We are going back today! Its free and...

Found this little gem walking along the street from our hotel. Saw the sign and was curious. Lots of jewelry for purchase, some quite expensive but some very reasonable. The girl working there said they...


More  



Found this by accident just walking down the street. Funny little pokey museum. Not very good lighting on displays but very interesting. Lots of incredible stones from all over the world and some very large. The range of jewelry created here needs to be seen to be believed. Beautiful pieces and very reasonable prices. Free to tour.

I discovered Lucoral quite by accident as I walked down the street! Located in what appears to be an apartment building, it's easy to miss. It's free, and well worth the 20 minutes or so it will take for a quick walk through. Some really lovely coral pieces, large jade carvings and the opportunity to learn the history of this...

We accidentally stumbled onto the Lu Coral Museum while strolling down Kuhio St. From the street it didn't look like much. But we walked through the small parking structure and hit the elevator button. When elevator opened we were in a different world.....lots and lots of coral things on display and then we discovered the jewelry department. Should not have...

This was a small, but very delightful museum. It showed an insight into Hawaiian jewelry. The owner of the museum and store make jewelry while you are there, which is awesome. Everyone was very friendly and talkative, particularly Liz in the gift shop who told me the history of the place and gave some great tips on local attractions. The...

address: 677 Ala Moana Blvd Ste 615, Honolulu, Oahu, HI 96813
review_list:
While in Oahu I had the opportunity to see two great, though very different, performances by the Hawaii Symphony Orchestra (formerly the Honolulu Symphony). The first was part of their "music that Pops" series and was "Disney in Concert". They had four amazing vocal soloists who were beautifully accompanied by the orchestra. The best part is they encouraged people to...


More  



Great to see them putting the band back together! Much Aloha! Had the pleasure of seeing 'Iggy' preform with the orchestra. What an ezception bit of culture made available for a very reasonable price! Recommend this to anyone listening for some fantastic music.....

I had never heard about the guest conductor at the Hawaii Symphony concert I attended last week, but I will never forget him from now on. Some maestros are robotic. Not Junichi Hirokami.
He rivalled Leonard Bernstein in his rapturous expressions—from delight to dolor. No baton for him—his whole body was swirling with dramatic rhythms. Throughout the performance, his face...

We thoroughly enjoyed a concert. Note there are no places within walking distance to have a drink before the concert and the prices and plastic glasses at the theatre don't do it for me. The quality of the orchestra is exceptional. Sound in the hall is also excellent. I am so happy we got tickets. It was a special night...

During a brief holiday where we took a cruise around the islands last year, we had the time to attend the beautiful Blaisdell centre and hear a performance of Mozart by the HSO. title: USS Utah Memorial, Honolulu
address: 1275 Saratoga Rd, Ford Island, Honolulu, Oahu, HI
review_list:
Our friends set the 4 of us up to see the wreakage of the USS Utah. 2 young ensign ladies picked us up outside of the Pearl Harbor Memorial and it was a nice ride over to the ship. The ladies were very informative to, during,and from the site. They gave us time to take some real nice pictures.In honor...


More  



If you have military ID, you can go see the USS Utah memorial on Ford Island. No guides, no audio, but worth the visit to this oft-forgotten memorial. Went to pay respect to the 60 Sailors entombed in the Utah.

On the opposite side of the island from the USS Arizona is the USS Utah Memorial where another of the three battleships that were sunk on December 7, 1941 and not repaired still rests. The memorial is very simple not as well known as that of the USS Arizona but it is another reminder of the tremendous loss we suffered...


More  



If you can get onto Ford Island, please make a stop and pay your respects at the USS Utah memorial. So much time and energy is spent on the USS Arizona altar the heroes of the Utah are like a second thought, though they suffered similar circumstances. Definitely worth your time to stop and think about what these crew members...

Hidden on the NW side of Ford Island, opposite battleship row, the USS Arizona, the USS Missouri and all the Museums is a quiet 70-foot pier and memorial to the wreck of the USS Utah, one of the first 'battleships' lost in the attack on December 7th. The pier, plaque and flag face the rusting hulk of the Utah, poking...

title: Kawamoto Orchid Nursery, Honolulu
review_list:
A plant lovers paradise. So many kinds of orchids on display. Bring your camera . Great chances for wonderful photos. Good prices. Plants can be shipped home.

If you are into Cattleya or Dendrobium, you'll love this place, they have great selections at an excellent price. I purchased an Onc Sharry Baby, absolutely love it. The plant is healthy and beautiful, every time when I get near the plant, the fragrance from the blooms just brighten my day!

Abundant display of multiple healthy, happy, breathtakingly beautiful orchid varieties. Kind and friendly service.

This was my second visit to Kawamoto Orchids. They have a great selection of unique orchids and great, friendly service.

Kawamoto Orchids is only about 6-7 miles from Waikiki, and it is like going to paradise. There are so many orchids blooming & available for purchase. They are packed & shipped for 2 day delivery. If you walk down to the lower gardens, you will feel like you are in old Hawaii in the mountain valley--so lush and tropical. Mr....


More  



From the moment I arrived and saw the vast array of greenhouses and orchids, I was entranced. My husband even got into the spirit with so many beautiful plants and flowers. There is a lovely koi pond inside and a resident cat named Gypsy who demands attention in such a nice way!! She kept hubby busy while I shopped...and boy....was...

title: Manoa Valley Theatre, Honolulu
address: 2833 E. Manoa Rd, Honolulu, Oahu, HI 96822
review_list:
Manoa Valley Theater is a delightful, quaint theater set back on the main road in Manoa. The intimate venue allows for great seats. The quality of the shows are considerably high. I have seen some excellent performances here for the price it is a resource well worth supporting for both locals and tourists.....Go see for yourself!

Saw a very good production of RENT here. It was our first performance and we will go back. You want to arrive early and stand inline as seating is general admission. There is beer, wine, sodas and snacks available for you while you wait, at intermission and you can take your drinks in the theater. Venue seats about 200 I'd...


More  



This is a very intimate venue. There is not a bad seat in the house. And, the price is very reasonable for the quality product.

I have enjoyed many shows at this theater. Seating isn't the most comfortable. Still, I look forward to seeing more shows at Manoa Valley Theatre

I am fortunate enough to spend summers on Oahu and make it a point to see at least one play each week I am there. Manoa Valley Theatre is hands-down my favorite theatre and the shows there compare to those in large mainland city theatres. Their actors are top notch and the set designs and costumes are over the top....


More  



Manoa Valley Theatre (MVT) does consistently strong, high quality work. Their 2012-13 season has so far included a very entertaining, smash-hit Young Frankenstein, a breezy job with the face Boeing Boeing, and Mamet's Speed the Plow. In recent years they have done excellent work with challenging pieces like Spring Awakening; they are currently presenting Next to Normal. The theater is...


More  



this small theatre in the middle of a graveyard ( that's right) is a gem. Its season usually consists of Six contemporary broadway and offbroadway plays with the best local talent in the Islands. Staging is imaginative and the quality is first rate.

title: Iolani Bandstand, Honolulu

When walking these grounds you wish the trees and the bandstand could talk...makes you wonder! I hope to see the band there soon!

Went on Saturday Feb 13 to shoot a video since I like to do spots that show off the island that would be enjoyable to both residents and visitors. Before going I read the different reviews and I have to concur with most of them. I was kind of disappointed.
I love nature and this is an oasis from city...

There are nice photo-ops here - a nice though small waterfall, a rocky stream, mature trees, and well-maintained lawns. But the city should downgrade this place to a neighborhood park. Very dissappointed. The grounds are litered with debris, not much in the way of any garden. Few trees, and a quaint waterfall...thats it. May be free, but a total waste of time.

I used to love it for the parking in the shade and eating lunch on a hot day and the scenery but that was over 20 years ago. Now there is very little parking - only in a fenced off area on Kuakini street and that is tiny and locked up a lot. Forget street parking. Forget water fountains. Forget...

This garden has a waterfall, trees and open space in the city. While some complain about the trash and homeless, we saw neither when we visited with the grandkids. There were a few locals enjoying the day...

You have to imagine when going to the place that once little Hawaiian children played in the beautiful waterfall. The park is located right in downtown honolulu ... downtown. You will always come across things you don't want to see at parks downtown. This park ends up being trashed by ignorant people and left trashed by even more ignorant people....

It's nice but small parking lot homeless trash and strangers hanging out. You get chicken skin going here!! Stay away if tourist.

My husband and I were already in the area, having toured the Foster’s Botanical Garden. After seeing pictures of the beautiful Waikahalulu Waterfall and Nu’uanu Stream, we decided to take a walk in this free, public park with the lovely shade trees and picnic tables.
Even before entering the grounds, the first sign of trouble was literately a permanent looking...

Kid time we use to spend each summer day at the falls, a favorite swimming hole. I don't think you can now swim there though for fear of getting ill due to the polluted water. But don't let this scare you for here is a pristine garden in the heart of Downtown Honolulu.

This attraction is so beautiful. I had not walked far when I came upon a friendly peacock who did not mind having his picture taken. review_list:
There are many places to enjoy dessert in Honolulu - Liliha Bakery's coco puffs, Leonard's Bakery's malasadas, Ted's Bakery's chocolate haupia pie - though my favorite dessert is the lychee/watermelon snow ice at Frost City. Not only is it healthier (made with fresh fruit juices and purees, frozen, then shaved to serve) than most sugary desserts, it's also a work...

Variety of unique flavors with a difference. Enjoyed the shaved ice with excellent service with a smile

I'm a shaved ice novice. But I like food and these snowy things are delicious. Not coyly sweet, just full of flavor. The Lychee tasted like the real fruit. There are little treats garnishing the plate, HoneyComb cereal (??? OK), tiny cantaloupe pieces, little orange balls that pop in your mouth filled with sweetness, etc...lots of food blings. The staff was friendly however the shave ice was good, but not great. It might've been the flavor we got, matcha. It was extremely powdery than most. The presentation of the shave ice was cute, it came out with mochi and a chocolate pirouette.

My local friend took me here when visiting...what a 'cool' place..pun intended. The stuff is awesome, soft,pillow fluffy ice within amazing flavor. I want more!

Completely not what I expected...An amazing show that showcases Hawaiian Mythology stories that is translated into beautiful costumes, choreography, singing, chanting, and of course a talented "top notch" cast. Needs more thumbs!! The show was amazing just with the hula dancers and the Hawaiian spiritual history, then fire dancers came out and I got pumped!

The show is rooted in traditional Hawaiian hula with a flare of contemporary music and stunning costumes that transport you to a mythical land where stories of the past come alive. Highly recommend it for locals and visitors alike!

Went to see the show "Myths" last night at the Princess Kaiulani Hotel. The show was fantastic--a must see for all tourists and locals. Beautiful costuming on kane and wahine dancers--go see the show!

Myth is a show about the legends and stories of the Hawaiian people. title: Ka’au Crater Hike, Honolulu

Honolulu is a now multicultural paradise but at one time it was home to a concentration camp imprisoning nearly 1,000 American citizens. The camp was known as jigoku dani or “Hell Valley” to those imprisoned there for nearly four years.
